Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA) is a progressive, non-inflammatory degeneration or dysplasia of rods and cones. First it leads to night blindness and later to blindness during the day. This disease is characterized by loss of vision starting with progressive loss of night vision affecting both eyes first followed by totally blindness. In dogs with PRA, firstly the rods are affected followed by cones. The eyes may have less pigmentation with slight sheen and the affected dog may bump into walls or into unfamiliar objections frequently, may show reluctance to go down the stairs or jump down steps and can develop cataracts,. Diagnosis is usually done with the help of ophthalmoscope and electroretinogram.
The age of onset varies from breed to breed and is usually between 2-5 years. Symptoms become apparent with progression of the disease.

The condition is reported in Bedlington Terriers, Cavalier King Charles Spaniels, Labrador and Golden Retrievers, Rottweilers, American Cocker Spaniels, and English Springer Spaniels, Old English Mastiffs and Bullmastiffs. The carrier frequency is around 17% in Papillons and Phalenes.

The CNGB1 gene is crucial for photoreceptor function. A nonsense mutation on the gene disrupts rods and cone and thereby affects electrical response to light. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of CNGB1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Progressive Retinal Atrophy. However, in Old English Mastiffs and Bullmastiffs the inheritance may follow autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance where one abnormal copy of gene is enough to cause the disease.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Diet with vitamin A rich food is recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Progressive Retinal Atrophy

Coat color, brown is an inherited trait influenced by the pigment eumelanin which causes the darkening of a dogâ€™s coat color. This brown color coat is also referred to as liver, red or chocolate coat.
Brown color coat trait is reported in many breeds including Australian Shepherd, German Shepher, Leonberger, and Miniature American Shepherd

The TYRP1 gene provides instructions for making enzyme called Tyrosinase-related protein. This enzyme is located in melanocytes, which are specialized cells that give pigmentation to the coat. A homozygous deletion CCT in TYRP1 gene results in an improper production of eumelanin leading to dilute brown coat color. It should be noted that dogâ€™s coat color is a polygenic condition and pigment inheritance is complex and influenced by multiple genes.
Coat color, brown

Amelogenesis Imperfecta refers to a group of inherited disorders affecting the structure, composition, and quantity of tooth enamel. It is a common non-syndromic genetic disorder caused by malfunction of enamel proteins, and results in enamel hypoplasia (thinning or absence of enamel), small and pointed teeth, rough surface with brown color, and greater gaps between teeth. The symptoms are noticeable in young dogs and become more apparent with age due to premature enamel damage.
Amelogenesis imperfecta affects pups as early as 2-12 weeks. Both deciduous and permanent teeth are affected and gap between teeth increases as the dog grows older.

The breeds commonly affected include Standard poodle dogs, Italian Greyhound,Parson Rusell Terrier, Akita, Samoyed group including Alaskan Malamute, Chow Chow, German shepherd and Spitz-type breeds. The prevalence of enamel hypoplasia in Italian Greyhounds is around 14%. In Parson Russell Terriers, carrier frequency of ENAM mutation is 9%.

ENAM gene provides instruction for making a protein called enamelin which is essential for normal tooth development. The 5-bp deletion on ENAM gene does not allow the gene to provide instructions for making enamelin protein which results in abnormal tooth development. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of ENAM gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Amelogenesis Imperfecta
Regular dental visits will help in effective management including prevention of pulp necrosis, secondary infections, restoration of tooth, crown therapy, smoothing and bonded sealant treatment etc
Periodic cleaning of teeth and maintaining dental hygiene goes a long way
Choose foods that are softer and less chewy
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Amelogenesis Imperfecta

Cerebellar ataxia is a serious neurological disease, caused by cerebellar shrinkage, a part of brain which controls dogâ€™s movements. Symptoms include loss of balance and uncoordinated movements along with tremors, dizziness, hearing loss, weakening of one or more limbs, head tilting, nystagmus, nausea and loss of appetite and abnormal gait. Diagnosis requires an MRI and CT may be recommended.

The age of onset and rate of progression varies from breed to breed (6 weeks in Finnish Hound, 8 weeks in Scottish terrier, 6-40 months in Old English Sheepdog and Golden Setter breeds). Usually, the loss of balance is seen at the age of 6 weeks to 6 months. The first sign is loss of balance which is observed by the owner, as the diseases progresses an abnormal gait can be observed and it would be also difficult to eat and drink for the Dog. With early diagnosis and supportive care, prognosis of the disease can be delayed, but there is no complete cure.

The condition is mostly observed in Finnish Hound breed, Scottish terrier, Old English Sheepdog and Golden Setter. Other breeds may include Airedale Terrier, Australian Kelpie, Bavarian Mountain Dog, Bernese Mountain Dog, Border Collie, Chinese Crested Dog, English Bulldog, and Rough Coated Collie.

SEL1L gene mutation related cerebellar Ataxia is a result of misfolding of Endoplasmic reticulum, a crucial component for cellular function. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of ENAM gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with SEL1L related Ataxia, Cerebellar, Progressive early onset.
Early diagnosis and supportive care needed.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Avoid stressful environment for the dog.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Ataxia,Cerebellar, Progressive early onset

Benign Familial Juvenile Epilepsy, also known as remitting focal epilepsy is a genetic disorder, characterized by the recurrent seizures in dogs. Symptoms include facial twitches, repeated rhythmic jerks, hyper salivation or vomiting, restlessness or behavioral change in the animal. Severity of abnormalities varies among puppies, whereas in more severe conditions puppies experienced ataxia with frequent falling. Brain infections, metabolic conditions like liver shunts may be observed in some dogs. Timely treatment and supportive care are necessary. Diagnostic tests such as EEG, MRI may be recommended.

The mean age of seizure onset is reported as 6.3 weeks with most puppies being affected by 1â€“2 months. Usually this benign disease can be managed well depending on severity. The remission of seizures can be identified according to the dogs behavior.
The condition is reported in Lagotto Romagnolo dogs (Romagna Water Dog) with carrier rate reported at 32%.

LGI2 gene plays an important role of protecting the brain against brain seizures during neurological development in the pruning phase. Mutation in this gene can lead to epilepsy. Benign Familial Juvenile Epilepsy is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of ENAM gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Epilepsy.
Anti-epileptic drug treatment, stress management and dietary management are crucial
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs.
Epilepsy, benign familial juvenile

Tail short, is an inherited trait. Dogs with trait have natural short tails (bob tails), but some can also have half or no tails. This trait is an advantageous one for the working dogs as this decreases the chance of injury.

The trait is reported in Australian Shepherd, Austrian Pinscher , Australian Stumpy Tail Cattle Dog, Bourbonnais Pointer , Brazilian Terrier, Brittany Spaniel , Croatian Sheepdog, Danish/Swedish Farmdog , Jack Russel Terrier, Karelian Bear Dog, Polish Lowland Sheepdog , Pyrenean Shepherd, Savoy Sheepdog , Schipperke, Spanish Waterdog  and Swedish Vallhund.

The T gene is important for normal embryonic development of posterior mesoderm which gives raise to somities which later originate into tail. A missense mutation on the gene results in short tail or sometimes no tail. The trait follows autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance where only one copy of mutation (mutation in heterozygous condition) is sufficient to express the trait. It should be noted that double copy of the mutation (mutation in homozygous condition) is reported to be lethal.
Tail, short

C3 deficiency is an inherited disorder that causes severe immunodeficiency caused by lack of complement component C3 protein that plays a crucial role in functioning of immune system. Lack of protein results in frequent bacterial and viral infections leading to pneumonia, kidney disease and infection of the urinary tract. Affected puppies also have an increased risk of developing hereditary muscle disease (hereditary canine spinal muscular atrophy). C3 deficiency predisposes affected dogs to kidney disease early in life which can lead to chronic kidney failure and dogâ€™s demise.
The disorder has an early age onset and the affected dog deminse due to recurrent bacterial infections. Untreated dogs may have shorter life span.
The condition is reported in Britanny breed, Bassett Hounds, Toy Poodles, Rottweilers, German  sheepherds and some mixed-breed puppies.

The condition is occurs due to a mutation in C3 gene, thereby inhibiting immunologic anti-infection reactions. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of C3 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with .
The surrounding environment should be clean
Should frequently get vaccinated
Avoid affected dog and carrier parents in the breeding program
C3 Deficiency

Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis, 4A is ARSG gene related Lysosomal storage disease. It is an inherited neurodegenerative lysosomal disorder that affects the central nervous system. Dogs with this lysosomal storage disorder have late-onset progressive behavioral changes, cognitive and motor degeneration, impaired vision, ataxia, seizures, and premature death. Dogâ€™s behavior shows anxiety, aggressive behaviour, and increased sensitivity to loud noises. For diagnosis MRI and CT scan may be recommended.

The age of onset varies based on the breed. Usually, the signs of the disease appear at about 6 months. The features at the early stage are mainly behavioral problems that most dog owners may disregard, until serious aggressive behavior, visual impairments, and motor defects appear. In severe cases, lethality is by the age of 4, as noted in Border Collie.

The condition is reported in Australian cattle dogs, Golden Retrievers, Chinese crested dogs, Chihuahuas, Cane corsos, Alpenlandische dachsbrackes , Staffordshrie terrier, Tibetan terrier, Polish Owczarek Nizinny, Border collie and American bulldog. 50% of American staffordshrie terriers tested are carriers.

Lysosomal storage disease, ARSG related, is caused due to the mutation in ARSG gene that codes for arylsulfate-G, a lysosomal enzyme. The mutation in ARSG gene leads to 75% decrease in enzyme activity. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of ARSG gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis, 4A.
Careful observation of dogâ€™s behavior and timely supportive care
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs.
Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis, 4A

Cerebellar ataxia is a serious, progressive neurological disease, due to degeneration of brain tissue (cerebellar the part of brain which controls the movements and body coordination). Affected dogs show loss of balance and uncoordinated movements along with tremors, dizziness, hearing loss, weaking of one or more limbs, head tilting and nystagmus. Due to equilibrium problems the dog can have nausea which can result in loss of appetite. Abnormal gait and uncontrolled movements develop in later stages of the disease where the dog cannot eat or drink. Along with physical examination, diagnosis is confirmed by MRI and cerebrospinal fluid (CNF) analysis.
This disease has an juvenile age of onset which can be between 6 weeks to 6 months. The symptoms usually worsen with time and progression varies from breed to breed.
The condition is reported in Gordon Setter and Old English Sheepdog.

A missense mutation on RAB24 gene derails crucial cellular functions and leads to Cerebellar ataxia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of RAB24 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Cerebellar Ataxia.
Early diagnosis and supportive care needed.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic. MRI, X-Ray and EEG may be recommended.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs.
Ataxia, Cerebellar, Juvenile to adolescent, RAB24-related

Coat color, agouti is inherited fur coloration displaying two or more bands of pigmentation. As a result the overall appearance of agouti fur is usually gray or dull brown and sometimes dull yellow. Agouti protein controls the release of melanin pigments (Eumelanin and Phaeomelanin) into the hair. Loss of function mutations on agouti signaling ASIP gene can result in recessive black coat. Coat color is a complex multigene trait.
The trait is reported in Husky, German shepherd, Daschounds, Doberman Pinscher, Boxer

The gene ASIP (Aspartic Peptidase, reteroviral like 1) codes for Agouti-signaling protein which is responsible for the distribution of melanin pigment resulting in black tan coat color. Inheritance pattern is complex, polygenic and autosomal in nature.
Coat color Agouti

Alopecia, color mutant is an inherited trait characterized by complete and permanent hair loss, resulting in a patchy appearance. Management is aimed at controlling secondary skin infections and avoidance of harsh grooming products and abrasive brushes which can worsen hair breakage. Mild shampoos containing sulfur and salicylic acid may be helpful in reducing follicular plugging. A balanced diet is helpful. It is a cosmetic disorder which does not interfere with petâ€™s quality of life.

The condition is reported in Chow chows , Dachshunds, Great Danes , Irish setters, Italian greyhounds, Standard poodles, Salukis, Whippets, Yorkshire terriers, Bernese mountain dogs, Chihuahuas, Shetland sheep dogs , Boston terriers, Newfoundlands , Schipperkes  and Dobberman.

The gene MLPH (Melanophilin) has a crucial role in coat color. A point mutation alters melanosome transport in melanocytes and leads to alopecia. The trait follows autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance where both the alleles are required to express the trait.

Coat color extension is an inherited trait. The E (extension) locus is governed by the MC1R gene creates the black facial mask of many dogs as well as yellow or red coats. MC1R activation prompts the melanocyte to produce eumelanin, whereas MC1R inhibition leads to the production of pheomelanin. A mutation of the MC1R gene can cause a dogâ€™s cells to only produce phaeomelanin in place of eumelanin. Mutations in MC1R have been associated with white coloring or partial red coat in several species. Coat color is a complex multigene trait.
The trait is reported in Irish Setter, Labrador Retriever, Australian Cattle Dog, Alaskan Husky and Siberian Husky.

The gene MC1R gene provides instructions for making a protein called the melanocortin 1 receptor. A non sense mutation inhibits protein Melanocortin making the coat color white or dull. Inheritance is not clear with both Autosomal dominant and recessive patterns reported.

Grizzle is a color pattern that appears as mixed hair on the dog with no discernible pattern. The color appears blended together, making it look like just one color until you examine it closely. Grizzle coloring may mix black hair with some tan or brown hairs, or white with black, making it appear grey. Coat color is a complex multigene trait.
The trait is reported in Irish Setter, Labrador Retriever, Australian Cattle Dog, Alaskan Husky, Siberian Husky and Afghan Hound.
The gene MC1R gene provides instructions for melanocortin 1 receptor which plays a significant role in pigmentation of cells. A missense mutation on the gene may result in Grizzle color coat.

Coat color black is an inherited trait. The dominant black gene is due to a mutation in a Beta-defensin gene (CBD103). Coat coloration is controlled by several different genes in dogs. . The pigment Eumelanin can modify and create other colors such as liver (brown), blue (grey), or isabella (pale brown). Note that coat color is a complex multigene trait.
Coat color black is reported in almost all dog breeds

The gene CBD103 plays a role in pigmentation of cells and a 3 base pair deletion results in black coat. The trait follows autosomal dominant pattern with only one allele with mutation enough to express the trait

Achromatopsia, also called as day blindness or color blindness, is characterized by cone photoreceptor dysfunction of the eye, leading to severely reduced or complete vision loss during day light hours. Dogs show signs of avoiding bright light or distress in bright light (photophobia), nystagamus (uncontrolled eye movements) and sometimes total colour-blindness. CNGB3 gene associated Achromatopsia is a rare genetic condition with complete loss of cone photoreceptor function while rod photoreceptors remain intact. Cataract development may also occur frequently in affected dogs. Cone function loss is confirmed by electroretinography.

Symptoms appear early between 8-12 weeks of age when owner observes pupâ€™s difficulty in negotiating obstacles. Initially cones start developing but once non-functional, their inner and outer segments gradually deteriorate, followed by a slow loss of cones throughout the dogâ€™s lifetime.

CNGB3 gene associated congenital Achromatopsia is reported in German Shorthaired Pointers and Alaskan Sled dogs.  Achromatopsia is reported in Alaskan Malamutes, Siberian Husky, Miniature Poodle, Wisehaired Dachshund, Rhodesian Ridgeback, Chihuahua, Australia cattle, Labrador Retriever and Miniature Australian Shepherd.

Mutations in CNGB3 gene cause dysfunction of retinal phototransduction pathway, leading to congenital Achromatopsia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of CNGB3 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Achromatopsia.
Although currently, there is no cure, clinical trials in the area of gene therapy are showing encouraging results for treating CNGB3 associated Achromatopsia
Avoid additional damage to retina, by walking the dog in shady regions, avoiding bright and direct sunlight.
Regular ophthalmic check ups, electroretinography as directed by Veterinarian
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Cerebellar hypoplasia, VLDR related is an inherited non-progressive form of neurological condition. It results due to inadequate development of cerebellum, the part of the brain which is responsible for responsible for coordination, balance and depth perception. The affected dog exhibits poor motor skills when starting to walk. Symptoms include general head bobbing, high or overstepping, clumsiness, poor judgment of distance, frequent falling , wide stance, tremoring limbs and sometimes vision problems. Hydrocephalus and epileptic seizures are not uncommon. The severity in lack of coordination is varied between dogs, from mild truncal sway and episodic falling to severe cerebellar ataxia. A mutation in VLDLR Gene causes Cerebellar Hypoplasia resembling Dandy-Walker-Like Malformation in humans. Behavior and learning capacity are not reported and all dogs were considered completely functional pets. MRI and CT scan may be recommended.

Even though condition is inherited, symptoms are seen around 6 weeks. As it is not typically progressive, it is unlikely for symptoms to become severe. Retaining enough coordination for basic functions, leads to a good quality of life

Cerebellar Hypoplasia is seen in Chow chows, Airedales, Irish Setters, Boston Terrier and Irish Setters. VLDLR gene associated Cerebellar Hypoplasia is common in Eurasier dogs with 16% reported to be carriers of VLDLR mutation.

VLDLR is a trans membrane neural receptor necessary for central nervous system. The single base deletion in VLDLR gene causes a frame-shift mutation, halting the production of the receptor. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of VLDLR gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Cerebellar Hypoplasia.
Although there is no cure, supportive care may ameliorate symptoms
It is advised to restrict the dogs activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Cerebellar Hypoplasia, VLDLR associated

Cerebellar abiotrophy is a rare, inherited, neurological disorder caused due to incomplete formation of neurons called Purkinjee cells in cerebellum. The symptoms of this disease include an abnormal gait which often appears as a goose-step involving the front legs, a broad-based stance, swaying, muscle tremors, head tilt and ataxia.  The disease can be diagnosed through complete blood count, serum chemistry profile, MRI and X-rays.
This disease has an early age of onset. Symptoms usually worsen with time and affected dogs have shorter life span.
The condition is reported in Beagles.

The SPTBN2 gene encodes for protein called spectrin beta non-erythrocytic 2 crucial for neurophysiology. A 8 base pair deletion disrupts formation of Purkinjee cells in cerebellum leading to Cerebellar abiotrophy.  It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of SPTBN2 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Cerebellar abiotrophy.
Pain management and medical treatment to protect nerve cells from damaging and improving nerve impulse transmission is helpful in delaying the prognosis
It is advised to restrict the dogs activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management. MRI and CT scan may be recommended.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Ataxia, cerebellar, KCNJ10-related is an inherited neurological disease characterized by loss of coordination. The affected dog shows wide-based ataxic gait which is more prominent in hind limbs, lack of co-ordination, and poor balance seizures, stumbling, staggering, tremors, and falling. Stress may lead to muscle spasms. The condition is usually diagnosed by MRI and CNS (Cerebellar Spino Fluid) analysis. The affected dog has a shorter life span then the normal dog.
The first signs usually appear around 2 months. Symptoms usually worsen with time gradually leading shorter life span.

The condition is reported in Belgian Shepherd, Jack Russell Terrier, Malinois, Parson Russell Terrier, Russell Terrier and Smooth-Haired Fox Terrier. The carrier frequency in Belgian Malinois is around 3%.

The KCNJ10 gene controls potassium metabolism central nervous system, eyes, internal ear and kidneys. A missense mutation on the gene leads to extracellular accumulation of potassium with subsequent neurological attacks. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of KCNJ10 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Ataxia, cerebellar.
Although there is no cure, supportive care may ameliorate symptoms
It is advised to restrict the dogs activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management. MRI and CT scan may be recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Congenital hypothyroidism is an endocrine disorder characterized by inadequate T4 levels early in life. Disease can be primary due to failure of thyroid gland, secondary due to pituitary dysfunction or tertiary due to abnormal hypothalamic function. The clinical symptoms for congenital hypothyroidism include dwarfism, protruding eyes and tongue, lethargy, retaining puppy coat, poor appetite, constipation, tremors, spasticity, mental retardation, delayed development, late dental eruption, and skeletal development abnormalities. Hypothyroidism is rare and under diagnosed disease in dogs. The diagnosis is done by simple blood test through which the T4 and TSH levels are measured.

The disease starts at an early age and if diagnosed early it can be treated well and the dog can lead a normal life. If it is not diagnosed it can lead to corneal ulcers, anemia, and a devastating disease called adult-onset megaesophagus, which will eventually could be life threatening.
Hypothyroidism is reported in French Bulldog, Rat Terrier, Spanish water dog, Tenterfield Terrier and Toy Fox Terrier.

Thyroid peroxidase is an enzyme responsible for irreversible binding of iodide to thyroglobulin, a necessary step of thyroid hormone synthesis. Mutation on TPO gene fails to produce thyroid peroxidase leading to primary hypothyroidism.  It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of TPO gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Congenital Hypothyroidism.
Treatment usually involves supplementation of synthetic thyroid hormone in tablet or syrup form by veterinarian
Giving a balanced diet to the Dog, regular exercise and ensuring proper intake of medications is important.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Hypothryoidism

Chondrodystrophia, is an inherited skeletal disorder that is associated with abnormalities in the development of cartilage tissues. Affected dogs show short limbed dwarfism together with excessive growth of skull bones. Other features include small stature, disproportionately short arms and legs with shortness of fingers and toes. The severity of the condition varies within and between breeds
The age of onset differs from breed to breed but symptoms can be seen from early stage in dwarf elkhounds, coarse and irregular bony trabeculae were reported by 6 months.

The condition is reported in many breeds like Alaskan malmute, Norwegian elkhound, Karelian bear dog, Miniature poodle, Labrador retriever, Deerhound, English Pointer, Pyrenean Mountain dog, Irish red setter and German shepherd. Carrier frequency of the ITGA10 mutation is reported to be 24% in Finnish Norwegian Elkhounds and 8% in Karelian bear dogs.

The ITGA10 gene codes for an integrin subunit of skeleton system required for growth plates of long bones. In dogâ€™s with chondrodystrophia, due to dysfunctional ITGA10 gene, growth of skeletal system gets affected. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of ITGA10 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Chondrodysplasia.
Pain management by anti inflammatory or analgesic drugs prescribed by Veterinarian are useful
For some dogs growth hormones may be beneficial.
Avoid heterozygotes breeding, as the progeny can be affected with this disorder
Chondrodysplasia, disproportionate short-limbed

Primary ciliary dyskinesia is a genetically heterogeneous disorder characterized by abnormally functioning cilia. The main clinical signs are recurrent or persistent respiratory infections because of the lack of effective ciliary motility causing abnormal mucociliary clearance. Progressively Recurrent bacterial rhinosinusitis and bronchopneumonia usually start within a few weeks of birth. Other symptoms include nasal discharge, chronic sneezing, coughing, exercise intolerance, respiratory distress, cyanosis and infertility in male dogs.
Primary ciliary dyskinesia typically affects young dogs of 8 weeks and younger. Rarely, it affects older dogs. The condition worsens with age if it is not treated on time due to bacterial infections.

Ciliary dyskinesia, is reported mostly only in purebred dogs such as Bichon frises, Border collies, Bull mastiffs, Chihuahuas, sharpeis, chow chows, Dalmatians, Doberman pinschers, English cocker spaniels, English pointers, English setters, English springer spaniels, golden retrievers, Gordon setters, long-haired dachshunds, miniature poodles, Old English sheepdogs, Newfoundlands, Rottweilers, and Staffordshire bull terriers

CCDC39 gene is required for assembly and function of body ciliary covering inner layer of the organs. The mutation on CCDC39 terminates synthesis of coiled-coil domain 39 protein, thereby resulting in Ciliary dyskinesia, primary. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of VLDLR gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Cerebellar Hypoplasia.
Routine exercise may enhance mucus clearance
Supplemental oxygen therapy may be recommended by veterinarian during acute episodes of life-threatening bronchopneumonia
Antibiotics will be prescribed for respiratory infections on the basis of bacterial culture and sensitivity testing
Try and avoid stress to the dog and keep surroundings clean to avoid infections
Try and avoid stress to the dog and keep surroundings clean to avoid infections

Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis 5 (NCL5) is an inherited, lysosomal storage disease characterized by depletion of Purkinje cells in cerebellum. Affected dogs may show partial or total vision loss, abnormal gait, seizures, behavior changes which include hyperactivity, dementia, aggression, and loss of coordination, ataxia, delayed postural responses and slow pupillary light responses. This disease can be diagnosed through MRI and CT scan. There is no treatment for this.
Symptoms are observed around 18-24 months. The condition is progressive and symptoms usually worsen with age thereby leading to shorter life span.
The condition is reported in Australian Cattle Dog, Border Collie, Golden Retriever, Dachshunds and Chihuahua. Carrier frequency reported at 3.5% in Border Collies in Australia and 0.035% in Japan.

The gene CLN5 gene encodes a functional enzyme required for eliminating the waste materials from the cell. A nonsense mutation on the gene results in production of partial enzyme which is degraded rapidly. This results in accumulation of waste material in the cells causing Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis 5. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of CLN5 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Neuronal ceroid-lipofuscinosis 5.
Although there is no cure, supportive care may ameliorate symptoms
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management. MRI and CT scan may be recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Leucocyte adhesion deficiencies are inherited disorders characterised by immunodeficiency leading to recurrent infections and a marked leuKocytosis. Typical clinical signs for dogs affected with LAD1 disease include development of omphalitis (infections of umbilical stump) and bacterial infections accompanied by fever occurring soon after birth. Affected dogs typically develop a progressive marked neutrophilic leukocytosis (high white blood count), accompanied by development of severe gingivitis, lymphadenopathy along with poor wound healing, pyrexia, and anorexia. Secondary bacterial infections usually become life threatening. Diagnosis may include detection of glycoproteins in white blood cells.

The age of onset is usually less than 12 weeks of age in young puppies. As the severity of the condition increases with age, the affected dog show signs of skin infections, impaired wound healing, anorexia, bone disorders, severe peripheral leukocytosis. Untreated dogs do not survive beyond 6 months.
This condition is reported in Irish Setters and closely related Irish red and white setter breeds.

ITGB2 gene, also known as CD18 produces Integrins which are specialised cell-surface proteins. When the gene is mutated, it does not produce integrins and results in dysfunctional immune system with decreased response to injuries and infections.
The condition can be managed by use of oral antibiotic therapy
Balanced healthy diet, clean and safe environment should be provided to the dogs
Recent advancements in gene therapy research recorded reversing clinical signs
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Leucocyte adhesion deficiencies are inherited disorders of primary immunodeficiency characterized by marked leukocytosis and recurrent bacterial infections. Affected animals die because of extreme susceptibility to infections, caused by an inability of white blood cells to pass from the blood stream to the infected tissue or site. Clinical signs include severe, recurrent bacterial skin infections, impaired wound healing, fever, gingivitis, lameness and enlarged lymph nodes. Diagnosis may include detection of glycoprotein on white blood cells.

The age of onset is around 10 weeks of age with average age of presentation to the veterinarian at 13.5 week with signs of recurrent infections, fever, gingivitism, salivation, and impaired wound healing. Untreated dogs often do not survive beyond the age of 6 months.

This condition is reported in German shepherd and a mixed breed of German shepherd and Rottweiler mongrel. Prevalence of the mutant allele is estimated to be approximately 5% in the US Irish Setter population, and 7.6% in the Australian Irish Setter population.

FERMT3 is also known as KINDLIN3 gene. Mutation in the gene results in lack of a membrane glycoprotein called kindlin-3 protein resulting in LAD-III. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of FERMT3 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with LAD-III.
The condition does not have a cure and should be managed by use of oral antibiotic therapy
Balanced healthy diet, clean and safe environment should be provided to the dogs
Recent advancements in gene therapy research recorded reversing clinical signs
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Canine multifocal retinopathy-I is an inherited, ophthalmic condition characterized by formation of multiple lessions, which develop around 13 weeks of age, the affected dog shows multiple tan-pink subretinal patches on  retina, these lesions which progress with the age of dog,thereby leading  to retinal degeneration and retinal pigment epithelial hypertrophy and pigmentation. These lesions alter the appearance of the eye but usually donâ€™t affect the vision of the dog. Sometimes, these lesions may disappear or may result in minor retinal folding. Opthalmoscopic changes are usually seen in affected dogs by the age of 4 months. The fluid accumulation under detached retina results in gray, tan, orange or pink â€œblistersâ€� in the eye.  Diagnosis is done by Opthalmoscopy.

The age of onset is usually at 13-16 weeks. Since, the progression of the retinal changes are slow, lesions appear to heal and are no longer visible during eye test , there might be little or no vision loss due to this condition.

The condition is reported in American Bulldog, American bully, Aussiedoodle, Australian koolie, Australian shepherd, Brazilian terrier, Bulldog, Bullmastiff, Cane Corso, Dogue de Bordeaux, English bulldog, French Bulldog, Great pyrenees, Koolie, Mastiff , Miniature Australian shepherd, Perro de Presa, Pomsky, Shorty bull, South African Boerboel, Toy Australian Shepherd , Great Pyrenees dogs and Havanese.

Bestrophinopathies are a group of retinal diseases caused due to point mutations in BEST1 gene which is necessary for retinal pigment epithelium function. The BEST1 gene codes for the protein bestrophin 1 which is absent when the gene is mutated. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of BEST1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Canine multifocal retinopathy-I.
Careful monitoring of dog's vision and regular ophthalmic check ups necessary
Vitamin A and E rich foods are recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Coat color, harlequin is an inherited trait. Harlequin dogs have a unique coat pattern, consisting of a white base color and scattered patches of black all over their bodies. In some cases, these black patches may even appear blue. Coat color is a complex multigene trait
Dog breeds with this coat pattern are very rare. The trait has been reported in Great Danes, Merles and Miniature Pinscher

A missense mutation in PSMB7 gene (protease subunit beta 7) which encodes the beta 2  catalytic subunit of the proteosome results in harlequin phenotype coat color. This follows autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance where only one copy is enough to express the trait. When mutation is present in two copies it could be lethal in embryonic condition.

Menkes disease, involving ATP7A, is a neurodegenerative disorder of copper deficiency.Â It is characterized by cerebral and cerebellar degeneration, connective tissue abnormalities, coarse hair and a failure to thrive. Symptoms are directly related to the dysfunction of copper dependent enzymes and there is a high variation in the severity of symptoms and if left untreated, may result in severe neurologic defects. The diagnosis is usually confirmed by analysing copper level in the urine.
This occurs at an early age and can be lethal if it is not treated. Phenotypic variability is reported.
Menkes disease is reported in Labrador Retriever, Doberman Pinscher, American Cocker Spaniel, Keeshond, Skye Terrier and West Highland White Terrier

ATP7A gene is responsible for production of the ATPase enzyme that regulates copper levels in the body. The missense mutation causes decrease in copper levels and results to Menkes disease. The condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern and affects only male dogs. Female dogs are unaffected carriers.
Frequent copper analysis followed by early treatment can alleviate the neurological symptoms
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier females in breeding programs

Wilson disease, an inherited disorder is caused by mutations in ATP7B gene. It is associated with copper accumulation in the liver and brain, resulting in hepatic cirrhosis and neuronal degeneration. Affected dog shows symptoms of fatigue, lack of appetite, abdominal pain, jaundice, speech and swallowing problems, poor coordination and muscle stiffness. Golden-brown eye discoloration (Kayser-Fleischer rings) is seen in some dogs. Affected dogs have high copper content in urine, abnormally high activity liver enzymes. Lethality is common in untreated dogs.  Diagnosis is done by checking copper in urine and liver biopsy (as recommended by Vet)

The condition has an early age of onset. If it not diagnosed early, the copper gets accumulated in liver, which leads to liver cirrhosis which is life threatening. The female dogs have a higher predisposition for the condition and severity.
The condition is reported in Doberman Pinscher, Labrador Retriever, West Highland White Terrier or Skye Terriers.  Affected Dobermans have predisposition to hepatitis.

ATP7B gene codes for ATPase, a copper transporting peptide, which is essential for excretion of copper into the bile via the apical membrane of hepatocytes. Gene mutations in ATP7B cause Wilson Disease. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of ATP7B gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Wilson Disease.
Although currently, there is no cure, diagnosis of Wilson disease and related copper toxicosis, helps veterinarian to take steps to prevent development of copper associated chronic hepatitis
Regular lab tests, medical check ups and includes chelation therapy are part of effective management
Dietary management should be implemented in a young pup and copper rich food should be avoided

Removing unaffected carrier dogs from breeding is not recommended in view of high frequency of the mutation, especially in Labrador Retrievers. Eliminating carriers could have detrimental effect on the genetic diversity of the breed
Research towards bioengineered liver stem cell transplantation for inherited copper toxicosis is underway
Wilson Disease

Craniomandibular osteopathy (CMO) also known as lion's jaw, is an inherited, uncommon, non-inflammatory, non-neoplastic proliferative bone disease that typically occurs in young dogs. It results when there is a bone swelling during the growth of the bones of the skull and jaw. Sometimes, only the jaw is involved. The most common symptoms of these disease include loss of appetite, intermittent fever, bulging eyes, jaw swelling and difficulty opening mouth. The dog may also show symptoms of depression. Diagnosis is usually done by examining X-rays. Treatment mainly aims at pain revealing and the condition is self-limiting. Usually by 12-18 months age the symptoms usually resolve.

Symptoms usually appear between 3-8 months of age. The prognosis depends of the degree of bony proliferation at the temporomandibular joints, the angular processes, and the tympanic bullae, which can limit the range of motion of the jaws
The reported condition is mostly seen in young West Highland white, Scottish, Cairn, Boston, other terriers and sometimes seen in Labrador retriever, Doberman pinscher, and Bullmastiff.

The gene SLC37A2 codes for a crucial protein that has plays an important role in osteoclast differentiation and function. Mutations on the gene disrupts this function and results in abnormal bone cell proliferation. It is an autosomal dominant disorder with incomplete penetrance where the expressivity of the condition may be absent or reduced even in the presence of mutation.
Affected dogs need steroid treatment to reduce pain
Spaying and neutering affected dogs can be considered
Craniomandibular Osteopathy

Cone rod dystrophy 1 is an inherited eye disorder which affects the rod and cone photoreceptors resulting in visual acuity followed by severe loss of central and color vision that often progress to blindness. Retinal thinning and degeneration is characteristic with rapidly progressive loss of cone function accompanied by progressive rod loss that is only relatively slower. Photoreceptors of inner and outer segmental layer are damaged, with rod inner segment more severely affected than those of cones. Diagnosis is done by eye examination and electroretinography

Affected dogs typically have thinning and retinal degeneration by 11 weeks of age. Evidence of retinal thinning can be identified on a veterinary eye exam by 3 to 6 months of age. Vision is severely impaired by one year of age and by 20 months of age affected dogs have an advanced stage of retinal degeneration.
This condition is reported in American Sttafordshire terrier breed

Cone rod dystrophy-1 is caused by a three-base deletion in exon 10 of PDE6B gene which codes for the rod-specific essential component of the visual cascade protein. The gene is pivotal in phototransduction. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of PDE6B gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Cone rod dystrophy-1.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Diet with vitamin A rich food is recommended.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Cone-rod dystrophy 1

The clinical signs include early, severe, and rapidly progressive loss of cone function accompanied by progressive rod loss that is only relatively slower. Photoreceptors of inner and outer segmental layer are damaged, with rod inner segment more severely affected than those of cones. Affected dogs typically have thinning and retinal degeneration by 11 weeks of age; vision is severely impaired by one year of age with advanced stage of retinal degeneration by the age of 20 months.
The condition is reported in American Pitbull Terrier dog breed.

The gene is pivotal in phototransduction. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of PDE6B gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Cone rod dystrophy-2.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Diet with vitamin A is recommended.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Congenital Stationary Night Blindness (CSNB), also known as Leber Congenital Amaurosis and retinal pigment epithelial dystrophy is an eye degenerative disorder. It is characterized by loss of night vision, progressing to low light and also possibly day vision being affected. Affected by RPE65 gene, the condition results in early loss of light sensitive cone outer segments, with slower loss of long or medium wavelength outer segments and rods. Diagnosis is usually done by ophthalmic examination and electroretinography

The affected dogs display profound visual impairment at 5-6 weeks of age. As the dog grows older, affected dogs may show retinal abnormalities indicating slow progressive retinal degenerative process.
This disorder is reported in Briard dog breeds

Leber Congenital Amaurosis is caused due 4bp deletion in the exon 5 of RPE65 gene which is responsible for regenration of 11-cis retinol in the visual cycle. A mutation in this gene results in the accumulation of lipid in the retinal pigment epithelium leading progressive retinal degeneration. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of RPE65 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Leber Congenital Amaurosis
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Keeping lights on at night to help your dog navigate is one of the best things you can do at home
Diet with vitamin A rich food is recommended.
Gene therapy research in preclinical trials and promising
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Leber congenital amaurosis (congenital stationary night blindness)

Hair curl or wavy coat is a inherited trait, which is dominant in nature, characterized by curls. These curls cover the whole body. These are small and dense usually give protection to the Dog from rain and from any rough brush. Dogs with this trait usually have more and longer fringes around belly, ears, thighs and back of forelegs
The trait is seen in Portugese water dog ,Bichon Frise, Chesapeake Bay Retriever, Curly-coated retriever, Irish Terrier, Lagotto Romagnolo and Spanish water dog

KRT71 plays an important role in hair formation. The allele CC is dominant and results in a curly coat. Only when the dog has two copies of the recessive allele the coat is of a non-curly type. The condition follows autosomal dominant with  incomplete penetrance
Curly coat

Cystinuria Type I-A is an inherited metabolic disorder that affects kidney function. Affected dogs will show no clinical signs of disease in the early stages with symptoms showing up late stages of the disease. While the disease is not genetically sex-linked, it is diagnosed in male dogs more frequently than females due to anatomical differences. Symptoms associated with this disease are increased urinary calculi formation, blockage of the urinary tract, inflammation of the bladder, blood in the urine and renal colic. The condition is diagnosed by X-rays and urine analysis. Kidney failure is reported in untreated dogs.
The symptoms usually develop in later stages of life, as the condition is asymptomatic until kidney stones are formed

Cystinuria has been reported in more than 60 breeds of dogs. Type-1A is seen in Labrador, Landseer, Newfoundland, Australian cattle dog, English bulldog, Dachshund, Mastiff, Basset hound, Staffordshire bull terrier and French bulldog. A relatively early age of onset has been identified in Newfoundlands compared to other breeds

Cystinuria, Type I-A is caused by a defect in amino acid transport in epithelial cells of the proximal renal tubule and intestine due to a mutation in SLC3A1 gene. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of SLC3A1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Cystinuria, Type I-A.
Management includes medical treatment with  drugs that increase cystine solubility , flushing out of the small bladder stones and surgical removal in case of large stones or obstruction
Â Â  Help the pet to consume more amount of water and provide low methionine, low sodium diet
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Cystinuria, Type I-A

Affected dogs will show no clinical signs of disease in the early stages with symptoms showing up late stages of the disease. While the disease is not genetically sex-linked, it is diagnosed in male dogs more frequently than females due to anatomical differences. Symptoms associated with this disease are increased urinary calculi formation, blockage of the urinary tract, inflammation of the bladder, blood in the urine and renal colic. The condition is diagnosed by X-rays and urine analysis. Kidney failure is reported in untreated dogs.
Symptoms usually develop in later stages of life, as the condition is asymptomatic until kidney stones are formed.
The condition is reported in more than 60 breeds of dogs. Type II-A is specific to Australian Cattle Dog

Cystinuria, Type II-A is caused by a defect in amino acid transport in epithelial cells of the proximal renal tubule and intestine due to a mutation in SLC3A1 gene. It is an autosomal dominant disorder, resulting when one copy of SLC3A1 gene carry the mutation. Risk to offspring is 50%.
Management includes medical treatment with  drugs that increase cystine solubility , flushing out of the small bladder stones and surgical removal in case of large stones or obstruction
Help the pet to consume more amount of water and provide low methionine, low sodium diet

Dental Hypomineralization (DH), also known as Raine syndrome is an inherited disorder of defective dental mineralization leading to extreme wear of the teeth that can be very painful for the dog. Browning of the teeth appears much earlier in life. Affected dog may also show Pulpitis characterized by inflammation of the dental pulp which eventually causes tooth death, requiring tooth extraction. Histologically, dentin of affected dogs has an abnormal structure and the enamel can be slightly hypoplastic.  The diagnosis of DH can be done with the help of radiographs

This condition affects the dog from birth but symptoms may not become noticeable until the dog reaches two years old in many cases but in severe cases onset can be much early. In the early stages cracking of tooth enamel, brownish spots or brownish discoloration of teeth are see which progresses to pulp inflammation and pain. Proper dental care is necessary to delay tooth decay and loss
The condition is reported in Standard Poodle dogs and Border coolie. It is estimated that approximately 11% of the breed population of Border coolie are carriers of this genetic defect

Dental Hypomineralization is caused by defective protein that binds together calcium and phosphorylates involved in dental bone mineralization due to a mutation in FAM20C gene. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of FAM20C gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Dental Hypomineralization
Regular dental cleaning and check-ups are mandatory
Treatment for the condition involves extracting worn teeth.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Renal Cystadenocarcinoma and Nodular Dermatofibrosis is an inherited genetic disorder of kidney. The syndrome usually features bilateral, multifocal kidney tumors and skin nodules, consisting of dense collagen fibres. Few dogs may show unilateral disease. Affected area usually becomes swollen, scarred, and shaped in an abnormal way. The kidneys may also show an enlargement or abnormal shape, and may also have cysts or atypical masses located within the renal areas.  In female dogs tumors within the uterus are noted. The diagnosis is usually done by ultra-sonography.

Symptoms appear at 6 years of age, and it may begin showing with small bumps under the skinâ€™s surface in the limb areas. They may also show up around the head area of the dog. Most dogs affected will develop cancer between 9 to 11 years of age with poor prognosis and metastasis.
Renal Cystadenocarcinoma and Nodular Dermatofibrosis is mostly seen in German shepherd dogs, and rarely in Golden retriever, Boxer, Australian shepherd dog and mixed-breed dogs.

A mutation in FLCN (Folliculin ) gene, a tumor suppressor, causes loss of ability to suppress the tumor, thereby leading to development of cancer. It is an autosomal dominant disorder, resulting when one copy of FLCN gene carries the mutation. Risk to offspring is 50%.
Early diagnosis and surgical treatment to remove the tumors is helpful
Avoid using affected dogs in breeding programs
Renal Cystadenocarcinoma and nodular dermatofibrosis

Coat color dilution in dogs is characterized by a specific pigmentation phenotype and sometimes it is accompanied by hair loss and recurrent skin inflammation. The dilute gene (MLPH or D-Locus gene) is responsible for this condition. Besides the hair color, the color of the nose is diluted and the color of the eyes lightens to amber.  The dilution of black results in grey, also called blue or charcoal. The coat ranges from silver to almost black. Note that coat color is a complex multigene trait.

The trait is reported in American Staffordshire Terrier, Beagle, Doberman Pinscher, German Pinscher, Large Munsterlander, Miniature Pinscher, Rhodesian Ridgeback , Chow Chow, Sloughi, Thai Ridgeback ,Chihuahua, Hungarian mudi, Hungarian pumi , Italian  Greyhound, Pekingese , Shetland Sheepdog, Shih-Tzu , Tibetan Mastiff and Yorkshire Terrier.

A mutation on MLPH or D-Locus gene disrupts production of protein called melanophilin in pigmented cells and results in a dilute coat.  This condition follows autosomal recessive inheritance pattern where 2 copies of mutation are required to express the trait.

Coat color black is an inherited trait. The dominant black gene is due to a mutation in a Beta-defensin gene (CBD103). Coat coloration is controlled by several different genes in dogs. . The pigment Eumelanin can modify and create other colors such as liver (brown), blue (grey), or isabella (pale brown). Note that coat color is a complex multigene trait.
Coat color black is reported in almost all dog breeds.

The gene CBD103 plays a role in pigmentation of cells and a 3 base pair deletion results in black coat. The trait follows autosomal dominant pattern with only one allele with mutation enough to express the trait.

Hereditary hair length variability in dogs is determined by FGF5 gene. When there is a lack of the hair growth termination signal which is due to mutation of FGF5 gene, the growth phase of the hair cycle is longer, resulting in longer hair. FGF5 is expressed in the outer root sheath at the base of the hair follicle. The trait affects only in a cosmetic way but it does not affect the health or well being of the dog.

The Trait is reported in Alaskan Malamute, Bulldog, Bullmastiff, Chihuahua, Cardigan Welsh Corgi, Chesapeake Bay Retriever, Dachshund, Dalmatian, English Mastiff, German Shepherd Dog, Labradoodle, Labrador Retriever, Norfolk Terrier, Norwich Terrier, Pembroke Welsh Corgi, Rottweiler, Samoyed, Schipperke, Shiba Inu and Weimaraner.

FGF5 performs a critical role in the hair cycle, where it acts as the key signaling molecule in initiating the transition from the anagen (growth) phase to the catagen (regression) phase. A 16bp deletion results in longer growth phase of hair. Long-haired coat length is an autosomal recessive condition, resulting when two copies of FGF5 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent
Hair, long

FGF5 is expressed in the outer root sheath at the base of the hair follicle. The trait affects only in a cosmetic way but it does not affect the health or well being of the dog.

The Trait is reported in Alaskan Malamute, Bulldog, Bullmastiff, Chihuahua, Cardigan Welsh Corgi, Chesapeake Bay Retriever, Dachshund, Dalmatian, English Mastiff, German Shepherd Dog, Labradoodle, Labrador Retriever, Norfolk Terrier, Norwich Terrier, Pembroke Welsh Corgi, Rottweiler, Samoyed, Schipperke, Shiba Inu and Weimaraner.

FGF5 performs a critical role in the hair cycle, where it acts as the key signaling molecule in initiating the transition from the anagen (growth) phase to the catagen (regression) phase. A 2 base pair duplication mutation results in longer growth phase of hair. Long-haired coat length is an autosomal recessive condition, resulting when two copies of FGF5 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent.
Hair, long

Bestrophinopathies are a group of retinal diseases caused due to point mutations in BEST1 gene, which is necessary for retinal pigment epithelium function. Canine multifocal retinopathy is characterized by multiple areas of retinal degenration. Along with generalized retinal degeneration, affected dogs may exhibit acquired post-inflammatory changes, and fundus changes. Signs of the condition include multiple tan-pink sub-retinal patches progressing to degeneration and retinal pigment hypertrophy. Diagnosis by ophthalmic examination and electroretinography.

The age of onset in affected dogs is between 9 months to 2 years with multiple discrete circular areas of retinal detachment with underlying fluid accumulation and lesions. As the dog grows older, the severity also increases.

This disorder is reported in Lapponian herder, Finnish lapphund and Swedish Lapphund.  The Lapponian herder breed is known to exhibit both progressive and non progressive form of rod-cone degeneration.

This disorder is caused due to a mutation in BEST1 gene , resulting in dysfunction of Bestophin protein. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of BEST1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Multifocal Retinopathy 3.
Careful monitoring of dog's vision and regular ophthalmic check ups necessary.
Vitamin A and E rich foods recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs.

Code Rod Dystrophy-3, also called progressive retinal atrophy is an inherited genetic disorder characterized by blindness due to degeneration of photoreceptors, cones and rods. The condition starts with degeneration of cone first followed by the rods eventually resulting in complete vision loss. Symptoms of affected dogs include loss of peripheral and general vision, loss of color vision and photophobia. The disease can be diagnosed by opthalmoscopy and electroretinography.
The age of onset of the condition can be between 7 months to 1 year beginning with peripheral vision loss followed by complete vision loss over several years.
Code Rod Dystrophy-3 is seen reported in Glen of Imaal Terrier.

The gene ADAM9 codes for a ADAM metallopeptidase domain 9 protein and a non-sense mutation terminates the synthesis of the protein leading to Code Rod Dystrophy-3. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of ADAM9 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Code Rod Dystrophy-3.
Vitamin A and E rich foods recommended
Regular ophthalmic checkups, electroretinography as directed by Veterinarian
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Cone Rod Dystrophy 3

Degenerative Myelopathy (DM), also known as chronic degenerative radiculomyelopathy, is an inherited disease resulting in progressive hind limb weakness and paralysis as there is a gradual loss of spinal cordâ€™s ability to transmit impulses due to degeneration of the white matter. The early symptoms include loss of coordination (ataxia) in the hind leg, dragging the hind feet, difficulty climbing stairs, jumping and walking. The intermediate stage symptoms include knuckling of hind feet, difficulty supporting weight, inability to walk without support and urinary and fecal incontinence. The final stage symptoms include paralysis. The disease is diagnosed by physical and neurological examination, blood and urine testing, CT or MRI scan and spinal fluid collection and analysis.

It is late onset disease with symptoms usually appearing between 4-8 yrs of age. The disease progresses quickly and the dog gets paralyzed within in 1year. Most of the dogs do not survive beyond 3 yrs after onset of symptoms.

Degenerative Myelopathy is mostly reported in German Shepherd Dog. Also seen in Boxers, Pembroke and Cardigan Welsh Corgis, Wire Fox Terriers, Bernese Mountain dogs, Borzoi, Cavalier King Charles spaniels, Chesapeake Bay Retrievers, Golden Retriever, Great Pyrenean Mountain dog, Kerry Blue terries, Poodle, Pug and Rhodesian Ridgeback.

The SOD1 gene codes for superoxide dismutase enzyme which breaks down toxic, superoxide radicals. A mutation on the gene results in failure of superoxide radicals break down leading to Degenerative Myelopathy.  It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of SOD1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Degenerative Myelopathy.
Early diagnosis and supportive care with physical aid needed so that prognosis can be delayed
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic. MRI and CT scan may be recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

GM1 gangliosidosis is a lysosomal storage disease caused by beta galactosidase deficiency and characterized by progressive neurological deterioration such as densely packed foamy or granular cytoplasm of neurons, mild demyelination, axonal degeneration, and significant loss of oligodendrocyte cells. In Alaskan husky, the affected dogs generally have proportional dwarfism, and develop progressive cerebellar dysfunction and limb weakness. Clinical signs include weight loss, ataxia, abnormal gait, tremor of the head, lack of coordination, strabismus and positional nystagmus. Affected dogs occasionally have an increase in serum Alkaline phosphatase and sometimes MRI might be suggested.
Clinical Signs begin around 6 to 8 weeks of age, and are clearly noticeable by 7 months of age.
This disorder is reported primarily in Alaskan husky. It is also reported in Beagle, English Springer Spaniel, Portugese water dog and Shiba.

A 19-bp duplication in GLB1 gene is the causative mutation for GM1-Gangliosidosis in dogs resulting due to dysfunctional GLB1 protein. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of GLB1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with GM1 gangliosidosis.
Although there is no cure, supportive care may ameliorate symptoms.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs.
Gangliosidosis, GM1 (Alaskan Husky)

Clinical symptoms in Portugese water dog include loss of coordination muscle tremors, muscle ataxia, loss of weight and wide based gait. The disorder may also have an impact of the dogâ€™s eyes as well, due to lesions of the retina and clouding of the cornea. Degenerative eye changes will be first seen as squinting and in end will progress to complete blindness. Behavioral changes will be present as well. MRI may be recommended for diagnosis.

The first symptoms occur between 5 to 6 months of age. Dysfunction of cerebellum in affected dogs results in progressive neurological degradation and asymmetric growth. Affected dogs may not survive beyond the age of 1 year due to severity of the progressive condition.
This disorder is reported in Portugese water dog.

Mutation in GLB1 gene is the causative mutation for GM1-Gangliosidosis in dogs resulting accumulation of lysosomes in neurons. Glycogen storage diseases (GSD) are a group of inherited disorders that are characterized by a defect in carbohydrate metabolism, which leads to accumulation of glycogen in different tissues (Liver, skeletal muscle, central nervous system, myocardium and renal tubules). Clinical signs of Glycogen Storage Disease II, also called as Pompeâ€™s disease include esophageal dilation, vomiting, and progressive muscular weakness, loss of condition, clinical heart disease, and myocardial hypertrophy. Diagnosis by enyme and urine analysis.

Canine GSD II in Lapland dogs is a slowly progressive disease with a gradual onset at age 6 months. Due to severity of symptoms, dogs do not survive beyond 2 years of age and in many cases euthanasia may be required

Canine glycogen storage disease type II was first described in a Lapland dog. This disorder is reported in dog breeds such as Finnish Lapphund, Swedish Lapphund and Lapponian Herder. Prevalence is reported as 5% in Finnish Lapphunds and 2% in Lapponian Herders.

A mutation in GAA gene leads to dysfunction of acid alpha-glucosidase, which is essential for the degradation of glycogen to glucose. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of GAA gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Glycogen Storage Disease II.
A diet high in carbohydrates in conjunction with intravenous dextrose solutions can temporarily manage crises of low blood sugar.
Many a times dogs may require euthanasia at about 1.5 years of age.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Glycogen Storage Disease II

Haemophilia B is an inherited hematological disorder characterized by uncontrolled bleeding due to absence of clotting factor IX in blood. Hemophiliac dogs suffer from spontaneous and prolonged bleeding from various areas, such as trauma sites, umbilical cords after birth, and the nose, mouth and eyes. Internal bleeding in body cavities such as the chest or abdomen can cause swelling that can be life threatening. The dogs also have anemia, swelling in joints or muscles, lameness, red- round pinpoint spots on skin and weakness. The condition is diagnosed by coagulation assays.
This disease has an early age of onset but is usually discovered the owner after routine surgery if post-operative bleeding becomes excessive or prolonged. If not treated it leads to lethality.
Haemophilia B is reported in Airedale Terrier, Cairn Terrier, German Wirehaired Pointer, Hovawart, Labrador Retriever, Lhasa Apso, Newfoundland, and Rhodesian Ridgeback.

The gene F9 codes for a clotting factor IX, and mutated gene fails to produce normal clotting factor. It is an X-linked recessive disorder where only males with mutation are affected and females remain unaffected carriers.

There is no cure for hemophilia, but the main aim of treatment is for bleeding episodes in dogs involves repeated substitution therapy. Usually intravenous whole blood or plasma transfusions are given until the bleeding can be controlled.
Gene therapy that uses adeno-associated viral vectors may be a possible treatment in near future
Avoid using unaffected female carriers in breeding programs

Ichthyosis are a heterogenous group of rare congenital hereditary disorders affecting skin cornification. They are characterized by hyperkeratoses of different severity levels and are associated with a dry and scaling skin. Clinical signs include formation of a strongly wrinkled, thickened and scaling skin especially in the region of the eyes and nose. These changes lead to a dry inelastic and lichenified skin of an untidy appearance in the affected dogs and a markedly swollen periocular skin. Secondary skin infections can be severe. Skin biopsy may be required.

Affected dogs, specially Great Danes present symptoms as early as one week of age with greasy, scaly, thickened, and wrinkled skin which is most severe around the eyes and on the nose. With susceptibility to severe secondary skin infections. Compromised lifespan is due to severe disease conditions.

The condition is reported in dog breeds Great dane, Golden retrievers, American bulldogs, Jack russel terriers, German shepherd, English springer spaniels, Labrador Retriever, West highland, White terriers and Norfolk terrier dogs.

Mutation in  SLC27A4 genes disrupts movement of long chain fatty acids across the plasma membrane resulting in Icthyosis. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of SLC27A4 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Ichthyosis.
The proper treatment of an Ichthyotic dog includes regular combing, bathing in special shampoos, applying emollient ointments to help maintain a skin barrier and prevent excessive water loss
A quality diet is essential; supplements of omega fatty acids are ideal.
Euthanasia within the first few months of life is common due to disease severity and quality of life concerns
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Ichthyosis, SLC27A4-related

Persistent Mullerian Duct Syndrome (PMDS) is an inherited and rare form of male pseudohermaphroditism characterized by presence of uterus, hypoplastic oviduct and cranial part of vagina. This occurs when there is defective Anti Mullerian Hormone (AMH) which is produced by testis during embryonic development. The affected male dogs have normal male external genetilia though, 50% will have one or two undescended testes (cryptorchidism) with risk of developing testical tumors and poor infertility. Complications of persistent uterus can sometimes lead to abdominal swelling,  fever, vomiting, and collapse. The disease can be diagnosed based by clinical signs and an abdominal ultrasound. The females do not show any clinical signs.
The onset is early. If the affected dog is not treated in early stages, the cryptorchid dogs are more likely to develop testicular tumors, which can be life threatening.
The condition is reported in Basset Hound and Miniature Schnauzer.

The AMRH2 gene codes for a Anti Mullerian Hormone which has a role in regression of mullerian ducts (female reproductive organs) in male dogs. . A premature stop codon results in non production of AMH leading to Persistent Mullerian Duct Syndrome.  The disorder follows sex-limited autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance where both the abnormal copies of gene are required to cause the disease. Female dogs do not show any clinical signs.
The medical treatment includes surgical removal of uterus and undescended testes by orchidohysterectomy
Surgery may be indicated to avoid and remove tumors
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Persistant Mullerian Duct Syndrome

Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis-12 is an inherited disease, characterized by degeneration of Central Nervous System (CNS).  Deficiency of lysozymes leads to accumulation of lipid-like storage material (ceroid and lipofuscin) in the nerve cells thereby leading to cell death. The symptoms include loss of vision, behavioral changes, cerebellar ataxia, tremors, and decline of cognitive and motor functions, sleep disturbance and seizures.  The degree of neurodegeneration effects and mental abnormalities increase with age of the dog. The condition is usually diagnosed by an MRI or a CT scan.
This disease has both juvenile and late onset which is usually at 5-7 yrs. The affected dog have a shorter life span of less than 8 yrs.
This is reported in Border Collie, English Setter, American Bulldog, Dachshund, and Tibetan Terrier.

Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis-12 is caused by mutation in the gene ATP13A2 gene resulting in ceroid and lipofuscin accumulation in the nerve cells. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of ATP13A2 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis-12.
Early diagnosis and supportive care and avoiding stressful environment is recommended
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic. MRI and CT scan may be recommended
Although there is no specific treatment, Gene therapy research results are showing promise for future
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs.
Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis-12

Rod-cone dysplasia 3 is an inherited progressive eye disease, characterized by complete blindness. It occurs as a result of degeneration of both rod and cone type photoreceptor cells of the retina, which is important for vision in dim and bright light, respectively. Affected dogs have abnormal thinning and degeneration of the retina beginning around 4 weeks of age, changes in reflectivity and appearance of retinal tapetum. Rod photoreceptor cells degenerate first resulting in night blindness, followed by cones resulting in color vision loss. The symptoms of this disease include peripheral vision loss, in the beginning leading to complete blindness. The disease can be diagnosed by performing electroretinography.
This disease has an early age of onset which is around 4 weeks. As the disease progresses the affected dog becomes completely blind by age of 4.
The condition is reported in Cardigan Welsh Corgi.

Rod-cone dysplasia 3 is caused by a one-base deletion PDE6B gene which codes for the rod-specific essential component of the visual cascade protein. The gene is pivotal in phototransduction. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of PDE6B gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Rod Cone dysplasia 3.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Diet with vitamin A rich food is recommended.
Gene therapy research is underway to develop potential treatment
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Spongy Degenerative Cerebellar Ataxia is an inherited neurodegenrative disorder with symptoms showing up at 2-3 months of age. Affected dogs show wide-based ataxic gait which is more prominent in hind limbs, lack of co-ordination, poor balance, seizures, stumbling, staggering, tremors and frequent falling. The disease is diagnosed by performing physical examination, MRI and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis. Histopathological examinations of the central nervous system reveal a bilateral symmetrical myelopathy, and predominant neuronal axonopathy.

The first signs appear before the age of two months with pet owners usually becoming alert between 4-8 weeks of age. Prognosis is rapid and dogs with terminal stage disease cannot stand, walk, eat or drink by themselves. Many affected dogs do not survive beyond adolescence.
Ataxia, Cerebellar, KCNJ10 related is reported in Belgian Shepherd, Jack Russell Terrier, Malinois, Parson Russell Terrier, Russell Terrier and Smooth-Haired Fox Terrier.

This condition arises due to a mutation in gene KCNJ10 causes dysregulated sodium and potassioum ion channel process necessary for proper functioning of central nervous system. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of KCNJ10 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Cerebellar Ataxia, KCNJ10 related.
Early diagnosis and supportive care and avoiding stressful environment is recommended.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic. MRI and CT scan may be recommended
Although there is no specific treatment, Gene therapy research results are showing promise for future
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Ataxia, Cerebellar, KCNJ10 related
