Factor VII deficiency, characterized by a deficiency or reduced activity of clotting factor VII is an inherited blood disorder. Affected dogs with factor VII protein deficiency can experience prolonged, uncontrolled bleeding episodes (mild to moderate) which is post trauma or post surgical hemorrhage. Diagnosis can be made on by checking clotting time
Clinical signs become apparent after surgery or trauma with excessive bleeding and a failure to heal after a traumatic event or surgery.

This disorder is reported in many breeds such as Alaskan klee kai, Airedale terrier, Beagle, Giant Schnauzer, Scottish deerhound, but it is also found in American Foxhound,  Finnish Hound, German Wirehaired Pointer,  Irish Water Spaniel,  Japanese Spitz,  Miniature Schnauzer, Papillon/Phalene, Sealyham Terrier and Welsh Springer Spaniel.

A mutation in Coagulation Factor VII gene causes lack of proconvertin, leading to development of coagulation disorder. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of F7 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Factor VII deficiency.
Safe environment should be maintained in order to avoid injuries for affected dogs
In case of surgeries on affected dog, ready access to suitable blood for transfusions must be planned.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

A gallbladder mucocele is defined as the accumulation of bile-laden, semisolid to immobile mucoid mass within the the gallbladder and causing variable degrees of extrahepatic biliary obstruction. It is caused by genetic changes contributed by factors including bacterial infections, hypothyroidism, hyerlipidemia and liver conditions. Clinical signs are often non specific and include  lethargy, vomiting, diarrhoea, anorexia, jaundice, abdominal discomfort or pain, fever, abdominal distension, dehydration, excessive urination, excessive thirst, collapse from septic shock. The affected dogs show increased levels of liver enzymes, and cholesterol.  The diagnosis of this disorder in affected dogs is by ultrasound examination.

In affected dogs, symptomatic illness averages for less than 7 days, although some dogs have vague episodic signs of vomiting and vague abdominal pain for months. As the severity increases the gallbladder becomes enlarged and if untreated can be lethal to the dog.
The condition is reported in Shetland Sheepdogs, Pomeranians, Miniature Schnauzers and Cocker spaniels.

This disorder is caused due to an insertion mutation in ABCB4 gene, which is critical for maintaining hepatobiliary homeostasis. The inheritance is autosomal dominant with complex and incomplete penetrance.
Medical treatment includes administration of antibiotic, choleretic drugs and hepatoprotectants.
In case of gall bladder rupture, emergency surgery is indicated.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Gallbladder Mucoceles

Krabbeâ€™s disease or Globoid cell leukodystrophy (GLD) is an inherited lysosomal storage defect, a neurodegenerative disorder. Clinical signs may include cerebellar ataxia, tremors, stiffness, impaired muscle movements, paralysis , hearing loss, vision loss, motor and sensory dysfunction. The pathology shows rapid degeneration of myelin forming cells or Oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system and Schwann cells in the peripheral nervous system. Diagnosis of this disease is usually done by confirmation of galactocerebrosidase (GALC) enzyme deficiency and by MRI or CT scan.

Onset of clinical signs such as pelvic limb ataxia, thoracic limb dysmetria and head tremor is around 4â€“6 weeks of age followed by inability to walk without falling and urinary incontinence by 12 weeks and complete paralysis of the pelvic limbs occurring at 15-17 weeks. The affected dogs do not survive beyond 2 years of age due to progressive loss of myelin and accumulation of neurotoxic substrate which can lead to incapacitating loss of motor and cognitive function.

The condition is reported in West Highland White terriers, Cairn terriers, Blue tick hounds, Beagles, Poodles, Basset hounds, Pomeranians, Miniature poodles, Dalmatians, Irish setters and Australian kelpies.

A causative mutation in GALC gene causes deficient activity of galactosylceramidase (GALC) leading to abnormal central (CNS) and peripheral (PNS) nervous system myelination. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of GALC gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Krabbeâ€™s disease.
Although there is no cure, physiotherapy, pain relief medications and steroids are helpful
It is advised to restrict the dogs activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management. MRI and CT scan may be recommended
Research studies using enzyme replacement and gene therapy are promising
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding program

Primary open angle glaucoma (POAG) is an inherited eye disease with progressive, late onset loss of vision. The symptoms include eye pain, watery discharge from the eye, lethargy and loss of appetite, swelling and bulging of the eyeball, cloudy or bluish eye are noted. The diagnosis is usually done by Tonometry and Gonioscopy.

The symptoms are usually seen in later stages of life, because the disease is asymptomatic until the disease progresses significantly. The loss of vision is also slow and progressive taking months or even years to develop.

The condition is reported in Beagle, Norwegian Elkhound, Shiba-Inu, Shih-Tzu, Akita Dalmatian, Alaskan Malamute, English Cocker, Spaniel Poodle, American Cocker Spaniel, English Springer Spaniel ,Samoyed Basset Hound Flat-Coated Retriever, Great Dane Siberian, Husky  and Petit Basset Griffon VendÃ©en.

The ADAMTS10 gene encodes for the protein ADAMTS10 protein which has crucial role in maintaining the structure and function of microfibrils in the eye. A missense mutation results in defects in the protein folding resulting in inadequate outflow of aqueous humour and a subsequent build-up of pressure inside the eye causing Glaucoma. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of ADAMTS10 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Primary open angle glaucoma
Regular eye check-ups are recommended.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.

Medical treatment may involve administration of analgesics, medications that decrease fluid production and promote drainage to keep intra ocular pressure (IOP) low. Long-term medical therapy may involve drugs such as carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, beta-adrenergic blocking agents and surgery
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Glycogen storage diseases (GSD) are a group of inherited metabolic disorders caused by defective glycogen breakdown with accumulation of glycogen in liver and skeletal muscle. Glycogen storage disease Ia is characterized by inability to convert glucose-6-phosphate to glucose, leading to chronic low blood sugar, accumulation of glycogen and fat in the liver, kidneys and muscle thereby causing damage and impairing the proper function of these organs. The affected dogs are hypoglycemic if fasted, develop lactic acidosis, hypertriglyceridemia, and hyperuricemia. Symptoms include weakness, lethargy, and anorexia. The condition is diagnosed by enzyme analysis, urine analysis, and ECG.

Symptoms appear early, and usually noticed as no weight gain and lethargy by pet owners. If it is diagnosed early the prognosis can be delayed, but the dog usually does not survive beyond the age of 1year.
The condition is reported in German Pinscher and Maltese Terriers with carrier frequency of 12% in German Pinscher.

The G6PC gene encodes for an enzyme Glucose 6 Phosphate which converts glucose-6-phosphate to glucose.A missense mutation in the gene produces an abnormal enzyme which fails to efficiently perform this conversion. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of PFKM gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Glycogen storage disease 1a.A missense mutation in the gene produces an abnormal enzyme which fails to efficiently perform this conversion. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of PFKM gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Glycogen storage disease 1a.
Dietary glucose and intravenous administration of dextrose recommended when dog becomes hypoglycemic
Â  Experimental Gene therapy holds promise for future treatment options
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

GM1 gangliosidosis is a lysosomal storage disease caused by beta galactosidase deficiency and characterized by progressive neurological deterioration Microscopic examination reveals occasional swollen axons and demyelinated fibers in white matter. Clinical symptoms include loss of coordination muscle tremors, muscle ataxia, loss of weight and wide based gait. The disorder may also have an impact of the dogâ€™s eyes as well, due to lesions of the retina and clouding of the cornea. Degenerative eye changes will be first seen as squinting and in end will progress to complete blindness. Behavioral changes will be present as well. Enzyme analysis may be recommended for diagnosis.

The first symptoms occur between 5 to 6 months of age. Incorrect function of cerebellum in affected dogs results in progressive neurological degradation and asymmetric growth. Affected dogs may not survive beyond the age of 1 year due to severity of the progressive condition.
The condition is reported in Alaskan Husky, Beagle, English Springer Spaniel, Portugese water dog and Shiba.

A causative mutation in GLB1 gene causes GM1-Gangliosidosis in dogs resulting accumulation of lysosomes in neurons. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of GLB1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with GM1 gangliosidosis.
Although there is no cure, supportive care may ameliorate symptoms
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management. MRI and CT scan may be recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding program

Gangliosidosis type II (GM2) or Sandoff disease is a lysosomal storage disease caused by deficiency of alpha and beta- hexosaminidase enzyme and characterized by progressive neurological deterioration. Clinical symptoms in the affected dog include loss of coordination muscle tremors, muscle ataxia, loss of weight and wide based gait. The disorder may also have an impact of the dogâ€™s eyes, due to lesions of the retina. Degenerative eye changes will be first seen as squinting and in end will progress to complete blindness. Behavioral changes will be present as well. Enzyme analysis may be recommended for diagnosis.
Onset of symptoms seen at around 9-12 months age. As the severity increases the disease progresses rapidly and dogs usually do not survive beyond the age of 18-23 months
The condition is reported in Golden Retriever, Toy Poodle, Shiba-Inu and Miniature poodle.

Gangliosidosis, GM2,Type II , is caused due to single base pair deletion in HEXB gene. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of GLB1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with GM1 gangliosidosis.
Although there is no cure, physiotherapy, pain relief medications and steroids are helpful
It is advised to restrict the dogs activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management. MRI and CT scan may be recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding program

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an inherited neuromuscular disorder caused due to absence of dystrophin protein leading to muscle atrophy and contractures. Affected dogs show stiffness in muscles, stiff gait, progressive weakening of muscles, difficulty swallowing, enlargement of tongue, diaphragm, and esophagus, difficulty swallowing, resistance to exercise, tremors, limb deformity and difficulty in breathing. The disorder is diagnosed by a muscle biopsy.
This disease has an early age of onset which can be between 1-3 months. The symptoms usually worsen with time and eventually lead to the demise of the dog.

The condition is reported in Australian Labradoodle, Border Collie, Brittany Spaniel, Cavalier King Charles Spaniel, German Shorthaired Pointer, Golden Retriever, Grand Basset Griffon Vendeen, Irish Terrier, Jack Russell Terrier, Japanese Spitz, Labrador Retriever, Miniature Schnauzer, Pembroke Welsh Corgi, Rat Terrier, Rottweiler, Samoyed, Tibetan Terrier and Weimaraner.

A nonsense mutation in DMD gene results in degraded dystrophin protein causing Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Inheritance is X-linked recessive with males affected more than females as male dogs carry only one X chromosome and females have two X chromosomes. Most of the females are unaffected carriers.
Timely medical management with proper physical aids required
Experimental Gene therapy with Crisper9 holds promise for future treatment options.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected female carrier parents in breeding programs

Generalized progressive retinal atrophy (PRA) is a group of inherited eye diseases characterized by progressive retinal degeneration that ultimately leads to blindness in dogs. In typical PRA rod photoreceptor responses are lost first followed by cone photoreceptor responses. Vascular attenuation, pigmentary changes and atrophy of the optic nerve manifest in later stages of disease. Clinical signs include Loss of night vision, loss of vision and eventual blindness. Diagnosis requires ophthalmic examination and electroretinography

Affected dogs begin to show clinical symptoms between 4-5 years of age. Progression of the disease leads to thinning of the retinal blood vessels, signifying decreased blood flow to the retina and progress to complete blindness.
The condition is reported Golden Retriever

A single nucleotide deletion in TTC8 gene causes Generalized progressive retinal atrophy  in Golden Retrievers. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of TTC8 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with GM1 Generalized progressive retinal atrophy.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Diet with vitamin A rich food is recommended.

Glycogen storage disease III-a is an inherited metabolic disorder, characterized by accumulation of glycogen in tissues caused due to deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme activity. This abnormal accumulation of glycogen in the tissues can result in the enlargement and dysfunction of various organs, including the liver, heart, and kidneys. The symptoms of this disease include slowing of growth, heat intolerance, easy bruising, low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), enlarged liver, swollen belly, low muscle tone, lethargy, and exercise intolerance with episodes of collapse. The diagnosis of this condition may need blood analysis and liver biopsy.  Affected dogs show increase level of enzymes such as AST, ALT, ALP, and CPK within the first year of life.
The onset of the disease is around 14 months of age and affected dog usually has a shorter life span.
Glycogen storage disease III-a is mostly reported in Curly-coated retriever and German shepherd. The disease in curly-coated retrieves is comparatively milder.

The AGL gene provides instructions for making the glycogen debranching enzyme which is involved in the breakdown of a complex sugar called glycogen, a major source of stored energy in the body. A premature termination mutation on the gene results in non production of the enzyme leading to accumulation of glycogen in the tissues. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of AGL gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Glycogen storage disease III-a.
A balanced diet should be given to the pet and stress should be avoided
Management of hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) is done with administration of intravenous dextrose
Although there is no complete cure at present, several treatment interventions are under investigation.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected female carrier parents in breeding programs

Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA) is a progressive, non-inflammatory degeneration or dysplasia of rods and cones. First it leads to night blindness and later to blindness during the day. In dogs with PRA, firstly the rods are affected followed by cones. The eyes may have less pigmentation with slight sheen and the affected dog may bump into walls or into unfamiliar objections frequently, may show reluctance to go down the stairs or jump down steps and can develop cataracts,. Diagnosis is usually done with the help of ophthalmoscope and electroretinogram.
The age of onset varies from breed to breed, from few months to 5 years. Symptoms become apparent which with progression of the disease and over time the dog can becomes completely blind.

The condition is reported in Bedlington Terriers, Cavalier King Charles Spaniels, Labrador and Golden Retrievers, Rottweilers, American Cocker Spaniels, and English Springer Spaniels, Old English Mastiffs and Bullmastiffs.

The CNGB1 gene is crucial for photoreceptor function. A nonsense mutation on the gene disrupts rods and cone and thereby affects electrical response to light. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of CNGB1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Progressive Retinal Atrophy. However, in Old English Mastiffs and Bullmastiffs the inheritance may follow autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance where one abnormal copy of gene is enough to cause the disease.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Diet with vitamin A rich food is recommended.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Progressive Retinal Atrophy

Ichthyosis is a heterogenous group of rare congenital hereditary disorders affecting skin cornification. The condition is characterized by hyperkeratoses of different severity levels and is associated with a dry and scaling skin. Clinical signs include formation of a strongly wrinkled, thickened and scaling skin especially in the region of the eyes and nose. These changes led to a dry inelastic and lichenified skin of an untidy appearance in the affected dogs and a markedly swollen periocular skin. Secondary skin infections can be severe. Diagnosis may require physical examination of affected dog and skin biopsy.

Affected dogs, present symptoms as early as 1-6 weeks. In few dogs symptoms can appear late at around 18 months. The symptoms usually worsen with time making it more difficult to move the paws. Compromised lifespan is due to severe disease conditions.
The condition is reported in American Bulldog and American Bully. Carrier frequency is high (34%) in American bulldogs.

A single nucleotide deletion on NIPAL4 gene disrupts epidermal lipid metabolism and causes Icthyosis. . It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of NIPAL4 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Ichthyosis.
The proper treatment of an Ichthyotic dog includes regular combing, bathing in special shampoos, applying emollient ointments to help maintain a skin barrier and prevent excessive water loss
A quality diet is essential; supplements of omega fatty acids are ideal.
Euthanasia within the first few months of life is common due to disease severity and quality of life concerns
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Ichthyosis, NIPAL4 related

Polyneuropathy in dogs is an inherited neurological disorder characterized by a dysfunction of multiple peripheral nerves. Affected dogs show generalized weakness, hypotonia, and muscle atrophy, particularly of the pelvic limbs, lack of coordination and instability. The condition often progress to decreased reflexes and muscle tone, paralysis, and sensory deficits. Diagnosis is usually confirmed by nerve and muscle biopsies.
Onset of clinical signs was observed at between 1 and 9 years of age. As the severity increases, the disease results in development of generalized muscle atropy and other abnormalities.
The condition is reported in Leonberger, Saint Bernard., Alaskan Malamute, Rottweiler, German Shepherd, and Golden Retriever, Siberian huskies.

A 10 bp deletion in ARHGEF10 gene neuronal dysfunction results in Polyneuropathy. Inheritance is not clear and could be autosomal recessive resulting when two copies of CNGB1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Polyneuropathy.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
Polyneuropathy, ARHGEF10-related

Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is an inherited skeletal disease characterized by fragile bones. The condition, which presents itself from birth is also known as Brittle bone disease and is caused due to poor collagen formation. The symptoms include spontaneous fracturing of the bones and teeth, loose joints, difficulty walking, pain, osteopenia, blue eye sclera, stunted growth, weak tendons and muscle atrophy. In severe extreme cases ribs can fracture leading to difficulty in breathing. The disease can be diagnosed blood workup for Vitamin D, Phosphorus, Parathormone and through X-rays and radiography.
Symptoms usually appear between 3-4 weeks of age beginning with fragile bones, difficulty in walking, pain. As the dog grows older the symptoms get worse, which can lead to lethality.
The condition is reported in Golden Retrievers

The COL1A1 gene encodes the protein Collagen which is crucial in bone formation. A Missense mutation on the gene leads to Osteogenesis Imperfecta. It is an autosomal dominant disorder, resulting when one copy of COL1A2 gene carry the mutation. Risk to offspring is 50%.
The condition is usually fatal and there is currently no treatment available.

Affected dogs, present symptoms as early as 1-6 weeks. As the severity increases, the affected dogs can be identified with severe exfoliation of greyish scales and mild erythema.
The condition is reported in German shepherd

Ectodermal dysplasia or Anidrotic ectodermal dysplasia, EDA- related is an inherited skin disorder, characterized by hypotrichosis, malformed teeth and reduced or absence of sweet glands. Affected dogs are born with lack of hair on the forehead and near the tail, malformed teeth (conical shaped) and few or absent sweat glands.  They show heat intolerance, frequent eye infections and fever. The disease can be diagnoised by performing physical examination and skin biopsy.
This disease is a congenital and symptoms can be seen at birth. The affected dogs can have a normal life span.
The condition is reported in Basset Hound, Belgian Shepherd, Bichon Frise, Cocker Spaniel, German Shepherd Dog, Labrador Retriever, Miniature Pinscher, Miniature Poodle, Pekingese and Whippet.

The gene EDA (Ectodyspalsin A) codes for a ectodysplasin A protein which has a crucial role in hair follicle placode formation, sweet gland cavitation, odontogenesis of tooth. A splice mttation in the gene terminates protein synthesis thereby leading to EDA. The condition X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance where male dogs are more affected than females because males have only one X chromosome and females have two X chromosomes.
Regular visits to veterinarian recommended.
Provide soft food and limit the amount of time spent by the dog in sun light.
Although there is no specific cure, intravenous injection of Ectodysplasin showed good results in some dogs.
Avoid use of affected males and unaffected females in breeding programs.
Ectodermal dysplasia, Anidrotic ectodermal dysplasia, EDA- related

Achromatopsia, also called as day blindness or color blindness, is characterized by cone photoreceptor dysfunction of the eye, leading to severely reduced or complete vision loss during day light hours. Dogs show signs of avoiding bright light or distress in bright light (photophobia), nystagamus (uncontrolled eye movements) and sometimes total colour-blindness. CNGB3 gene associated Achromatopsia is a rare genetic condition with complete loss of cone photoreceptor function while rod photoreceptors remain intact. Cataract development may also occur frequently in affected dogs. Diagnosis is by ophthalmic evaluation and electroretinography.

Symptoms appear early between 8-12 weeks of age when owner observes pupâ€™s difficulty in negotiating obstacles. Initially cones start developing but once non-functional, their inner and outer segments gradually deteriorate, followed by a slow loss of cones throughout the dogâ€™s lifetime. Cone function loss is confirmed by electroretinography.
CNGA3 gene associated congenital Achromatopsia is reported in GermanShepards and Labrador Retrievers.

Mutation in CNGA3 gene causes dysfunction of retinal phototransduction pathway, leading to congenital Achromatopsia-2. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of CNGA3 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Achromatopsia-2.
Although currently, there is no cure, clinical trials in the area of gene therapy are showing encouraging results for treating CNGA3 associated Achromatopsia-2.
Avoid additional damage to retina, by walking the dog in shady regions, avoiding bright and direct sunlight.
Regular ophthalmic check ups
Avoid using affected dogs   in breeding programs
Achromatopsia-2

Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA) is a progressive, non-inflammatory degeneration or dysplasia of rods and cones. First it leads to night blindness and later to blindness during the day. This disease is characterized by loss of vision starting with progressive loss of night vision affecting both eyes first followed by totally blindness. In dogs with PRA, firstly the rods are affected followed by cones. The eyes may have less pigmentation with slight sheen and the affected dog may bump into walls or into unfamiliar objections frequently, may show reluctance to go down the stairs or jump down steps and can develop cataracts,. Diagnosis is usually done with the help of ophthalmoscope and electroretinogram.
The age of onset varies from breed to breed, from few months to 5 years. Symptoms become apparent which with progression of the disease and over time the dog can becomes completely blind.
The condition is reported in Shetland Sheepdog.

A stop codon mutation in CNGA1 gene disrupts rods and cone and thereby affects electrical response to light. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of CNGB1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Progressive Retinal Atrophy.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Diet with vitamin A rich food is recommended.
Diet with vitamin A rich food is recommended.

Scott syndrome is an inherited, hematological disorder characterized by excessive blood loss due to deficiency of platelet binding of factor X. The affected dogs commonly develop excessive bruising and bleeding associated with surgery, veterinary dental procedures, or traumatic events. In addition, some affected dogs may also develop spontaneous, non-traumatic bleeding episodes including severe nosebleeds, bruising, bleeding in joints, and excessive bleeding during teething. The disease can be diagnosed by performing platelet function tests
This disease has an early age of onset and affected dogs usually have a shorter life span.
Scott syndrome is reported in German shepherd

The ANO6 gene (also known as TMEM16F gene) codes for a multi-pass transmembrane protein, an essential component of clotting system. A nonsense mutation on the gene disrupts the protein and leads to Scott syndrome. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of ANO6 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Scott syndrome.
Safe environment should be maintained in order to avoid injuries for affected dogs.
In case of surgeries on affected dog, ready access to suitable blood for transfusions must be planned
Avoid use of affected males and unaffected females in breeding programs.
Scott syndrome

Pituitary dwarfism is an inherited developmental disorder.  Affected dogâ€™s body is longer than normal, legs shorter with bulging eyes, swollen abdomen, short jaw and under-bite, large head, feet turn outward, swollen joints, bowed front legs, darkened skin, tongue sticking out of mouth with high pitched puppy bark and small testicles in male dog. The dog will have developmental delay, poor teeth and coat development, breathing difficulty, hair loss and poor responsiveness. Diagnosis is usually done by testing growth hormones such as TSH, FSH,TRL, GHRH.
This disease has an early age of onset at around 3months. The affected dog usually has a shorter life span.
The condition is reported in German Shepherds, Weimaraners, Spitz, Dachshunds, Corgis, Basset Hounds, Saarloos Wolfdogs, and Czechoslovakian Wolfdogs.

The LHX3 gene required for pituitary development and motor neuron specification is disrupted by a premature stop codon mutation resulting in Pituitary dwarfism. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of CNGB1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Pituitary dwarfism.
Although there is no complete cure, replenishing the hormones can delay prognosis and prolong life span.
Avoid use of affected males and unaffected females in breeding programs.
Dwarfism, Pituitary

Hereditary hair length variability in dogs is determined by FGF5 gene. When there is a lack of the hair growth termination signal which is due to mutation of FGF5 gene, the growth phase of the hair cycle is longer, resulting in longer hair. FGF5 is expressed in the outer root sheath at the base of the hair follicle. The trait affects only in a cosmetic way but it does not affect the health or well being of the dog.

The trait is seen in Alaskan Malamute, Bulldog, Bullmastiff, Chihuahua, Cardigan Welsh Corgi, Chesapeake Bay Retriever, Dachshund, Dalmatian, English Mastiff, German Shepherd Dog, Labradoodle, Labrador Retriever, Norfolk Terrier, Norwich Terrier, Pembroke Welsh Corgi, Rottweiler, Samoyed, Schipperke, Shiba Inu and Weimaraner.

FGF5 performs a critical role in the hair cycle, where it acts as the key signaling molecule in initiating the transition from the anagen (growth) phase to the catagen (regression) phase. A loss of function mutation results in longer growth phase of hair. Long-haired coat length is an autosomal recessive condition, resulting when two copies of FGF5 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent.
Hair, length

Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is a slowly progressive, irreversible, inherited kidney disease that can result in renal failure. This leads to a decrease in the amount of kidney tissue that is available to remove waste products from the bloodstream. Over time, affected dogs begin to develop signs of chronic kidney disease. Symptoms include enlarged kidneys, increased thrist, frequent urination, lethargy, lack of appetite, weight loss, weakness, vomiting and high blood pressure. Diagnosis may require complete blood count, radiography, renal ultrasonography and urine analysis.

The clinical signs of polycystic kidney disease are often first observed in mature, middle-aged dogs. In later stages, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea may occur, as a result of waste product buildup within the blood stream. As the dog ages, these cysts gradually begin to increase in both size and number leading to chronic kidney failure.
The condition is reported in Bull terrier, Cairn Terriers and West Highlight White Terriers

This disorder is caused due to a missense mutation in PKD1gene which is essential renal tubular structure and function. Polycystic kidney disease follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance where one abnormal copy of the gene is enough to cause the disease.
Early diagnosis, medical attention and disease management will help in delaying the prognosis
Avoid using affected dogs in breeding programs.
Polycystic kidney disease

Urolithiasis is an inherited disorder, characterized by formation of stones in the urinary bladder. The formation of bladder stones (calculi) is associated with precipitation and crystal formation of a variety of minerals this occurs when the fraction of uric acid transfer is low. The symptoms of this disease include frequent urination, blood in the urine, lethargy, depression, reduced appetite, pain, vomiting and in some cases inability to urinate. The disease can be diagnosed by X-rays.
Age of onset is around 6 months. The affected dog usually has a shorter life span due to accumulation of harmful substances in the body.

The condition is reported in American Staffordshire Terrier, Australian Shepherd, German Shepherd Dog, Giant Schnauzer, Parson (Jack) Russell Terrier, Labrador Retriever, Large Munsterlander, Pomeranian, South African Boerboel, and Weimaraner breeds. All Dalmations are at risk.

A missense mutation in SLC2A9 gene results in low fractional excretion of uric acid there by accumulating the minerals which crystallize to form stones in the bladder. . It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of SLC2A9 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Urolithiasis. All Dalmations are reported to be homozygous in some studies, that is with both copies carrying the mutation.
Dietary management, non surgical urohydropropulsion or in case of large stones surgery are recommended based on the size of the stones and severity of the condition.
Â  Consumption of more water is recommended
Â Â Â  Vitamin C and D supplementation should be avoided
Â  Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Hypocatalasia, also known as acatalasemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by impaired catalase activity in the erythrocytes or red blood cells (RBC). It relates to reduced activity of the catalase enzyme that is commonly found in the red blood cells, in mucous membranes, in liver, muscles and skin.  Due to this condition, the affected dogs have a higher risk of developing open sores (ulcers) inside the mouth resulting in gangrene. Ulcerations cause an increased susceptibility to oral infections, which must be monitored closely.
Affected dogs are most commonly asymptomatic, with oral gangrene and ulcers becoming more obvious with age.
The condition is reported in American Foxhound, Beagle and Carolina d

This disorder is caused by a point mutation CAT gene that leads impaired catalse activity in erythrocytes. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of CAT gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Hypocatalasia.
Treatment options include regular dental care, antibiotics, and soothing mouth sprays and rinses.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Hereditary footpad hyperkeratosis (HFH), also known as digital hyperkeratosis or corny feet, is a hyperkeratosis condition characterized by the thickening and hardening of the skin and growth of hair on the bottom of the dogâ€™s paw pads. Hyperkeratosis occurs when too much keratin is produced and is caused by many factors such as age, zinc deficiency, infectious, auto immune diseases and genetic mutations. Symptoms in affected dogs include dry appearance on the skin, flaking skin, skin cracks and bleeding, limping, whining, changes in mood, excessive itching, lethargy and aggressive behavior when skin is touched.
The age of onset is usually as early as 4 to 5 months old. If the disease is left untreated in affected dogs, it can lead to painful skin cracking and can create secondary infections in dogs.
The condition is reported in Golden Retrievers, Labradors, Bedlington/Irish Terriers, English Bulldogs, Boxers, Dogues de Bordeaux, French Bulldogs and Kromfohrlander.

This disorder is caused due to a missense mutation in FAM83G gene altering epidermal or skin cell differentiation. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of FAM83G gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Hyperkeratosis.
Â Â  Treatment and management options include regular skin and foot care and antibiotics
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management.
Safe environment should be maintained to prevent infections
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Epidermolytic hyperkeratosis disorder is a form of Ichthyosis, affecting the skin in dogs. The affected dogs have multifocal regions of pigmented scale with alopecia and roughening of the skin. The condition can be diagnosed on light microscopy by an experienced dermatopathologist. Affected dogs display lesions from birth and during adulthood they display generalized, pigmented hyperkeratosis with epidermal fragility and susceptibility to skin infections.

Although signs are identified within hours after birth, skin fragility is prominently noted in adult dogs with hyperpigmentation displaying generalized dark grey spots. Several affected dogs over 10 years of age were identified in which clinical lesions remained static once they reached adulthood.
The condition is reported in Norfolk terrier dogs, Labrador retriever and Cavalier King charles spaniels.

This disease is caused due a single base change in KRT10 gene resulting in hypergranulosis and hyperkeratosis of skin. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of KRT10 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Epidermolytic hyperkeratosis.
Treatment and management options include regular skin and antibiotics
Frequent bathing to control the scaling as well as the secondary infections is required
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management.
Safe environment should be maintained to prevent infections
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Hypomyelination syndrome (HS) is an inherited condition characterised by a reduction or absence of myelin in the axons of the central nervous system (CNS) exclusively.  This syndrome is also known as Shaking puppy syndrome or canine hypomyelination. Examinations of the affected puppy show drop of number of oligodendrocytes. Symptoms in affected dogs include tremors, lack of coordination and muscle weakness. It may in some dogs cause incontinence. Diagnosis may require physical examination, X-rays and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis.

A generalized tremor is observed between 12 to 14 days of age. The severity of the tremor varies between breeds. However, the tremors are diminished with time by 3 to 4 months of age, though some dogs, as they grow old, may retain persistent fine tremor in the hind limbs.
Hypomyelination syndrome was firstly described in Weimaraner dogs. It is also reported in Chow Chow , Bernese mountain dogs, Samoyeds, Dalmatians and Springer spaniels.

This disorder is caused due to single base deletion in FNIP2 gene. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of FNIP2 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Hypomyelination syndrome.
Â Â Â  Physiotherapy, exercises and water-based physical therapy helpful.Â
Well-padded bedding and soft, comfortable things should be available for your pet to rest on.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Intestinal cobalamin malabsorption is an inherited disease, characterized by inability to make adequate amounts of a protein that plays a role in absorption of Cobalamin (vitamin B12) an essential micro-nutrient for intestinal tract and kidneys. Affected dogs have increased levels of methylmalonic acid in their urine after weaning. The symptoms of this disease include anorexia, lethargy, poor weight gain, poor muscle mass, degenerative liver disease, and in rare circumstances, a severe neurological dysfunction called hepatic encephalopathy that can lead to altered mental state, seizures, coma and death. The condition is diagnosed through complete blood count (CBC), serum levels of vitamin B12, urine and stool analysis.

Symptoms usually appear between 12-14 weeks of age. The condition persists lifelong and needs management. Affected dogs will continue to pass increased amounts of certain proteins in the urine even with cobalamin supplementation.  If cobalamin is not supplemented it might result early demise of the dog.
The condition is reported in Beagle, Border Collie and Komondor. It is estimated that the carrier frequency is 6-7% in Border Collies.

The gene CUBN plays a crucial role in lipoprotein, vitamin and iron metabolism by facilitating their uptake. A single base deletion, causes Intestinal cobalamin malabsorption. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of CUBN gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Intestinal cobalamin malabsorption.
Dietary Cobalamin supplementation is recommended
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Canine polyneuropathy is an inherited, progressive neurological disorder characterized by a dysfunction of multiple peripheral nerves. According to histopathological studies, affected dogs exhibit a spongiform encephalopathy characterized by accumulations of abnormal, membrane bound vacuoles of various sizes in neuronal cell bodies, axons and adrenal cells. In affected dogs, symptoms include breathing problems, vocal cord paralysis, and respiratory distress, limb weakness, decreased or absent reflexes, numbness, abnormal gait, ataxia, decreased gastrointestinal mobility, distal weakness and reduced spinal reflexes. In some affected dogs, the eyes were abnormally small with cataracts. Diagnosis may require blood and urine analysis.
The first symptoms appear around 3 months of age. Due to the progressive nature of this disease, most affected dogs have a short life span.
The condition is reported in Black Russian Terrier, Rottweiler and Alaskan husky

This disorder is caused due to a single base deletion in the RAB3GAP1 gene causing dysfunction of peripheral nerves. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of RAB3GAP1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with canine polyneuropathy.
Although there is no complete cure, replenishing the hormones can delay prognosis and prolong life span.
It is advised to restrict the dogs activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

L-2-Hydroxyglutaric aciduria (L-2-HGA) is a hereditary neurometabolic disorder that is characterised by accumulation of L-2-hydroxyglutaric acid (L2HG) within various tissues, including cerebrospinal fluid and plasma leading to elevated oxidative stress and decreased neuronal cells. The most common symptoms are seizures, tremors, ataxia and dementia. Some affected dogs show subtle behavioural changes such as staring into space, becoming fixated on and staring at objects, pacing, circling, and walking into a wall.  Diagnosis is usually by confirmation of  L-2- hydroxyglutaricacidemia in cerebral spinal fluid, blood and urine.
The disorder usually starts to affect dogs early in life from about 4 months of age, getting progressively worse and is ultimately fatal.
The condition is reported in Staffordshire Bull Terrier, West Highland Terrier and Yorkshire Terrier.

The condition results due to a mutation in L2HGDH gene leading to accumulation of L-2-hydroxyglutaric acid (L2HG) in cerebral spinal fluid and plasma. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of L2HGDH gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with canine L-2-Hydroxyglutaric aciduria.
Although currently, there is no cure, clinical trials in the area of gene therapy are showing encouraging results for treating CNGA3 associated Achromatopsia-2.
It is advised to restrict the dogs activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Macular Corneal dystrophy is an inherited disease, characterized by accumulation of carbohydrates (known as glycosaminoglycans) in cornea of the eye.Some affected dogs will display growth of new blood vessels across the surface of their corneas. The disease will typically progress to compromise vision. The symptoms of the disease include white or grayish cloud in the center of the eye, watery eyes, dry eyes, glare, sensitivity to light and Corneal erosions. Diagnosis is done by ocular examination.
Symptoms usually appear between 4-6 years of dogs (middle aged dogs). If the disease is progressive and it is not treated it might lead to blindness.
The condition is reported in Labrador Retrievers Boston terriers, Chihuahuas, and Dachshunds. Carrier frequency is reported at 3.3% in Labrador Retrievers.

The gene LOC489707 (CHST6) has a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolic process. A missense mutation causes prohibits this activity resulting in accumulation of carbohydrates. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of LOC489707 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with canine Macular Corneal dystrophy.

In most cases, there is no prescribed treatment. But in cases of corneal dystrophy a topical acid treatment may be recommended for comfort and pain relief. It helps to dissolve the mineral deposits that lead to ulcers.
Low fat diet is recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Myotonia is an inherited disease, characterized by progressive muscle wasting and weakness. This causes muscle hypertrophy in dogs as well as noticeable stiffness upon rising to a standing position due to inability of chloride mobility and electrical instability in muscle membrane. Affected dog displays muscle stiffness, strange gait, enlarged tongue with difficulty to swallow, craniofacial structure anomalies and furrowing on several muscles when they are struck. The diagnosis of this disease are based on clinical signs, an electromyography (EMG) and a muscle biopsy report.
Myotonia has an early age of onset with symptoms seen within weeks from birth. If the dog is not diagnosed and treated on time, the condition can be lethal.
The condition is reported in Cavalier King Charles Spaniels, Chow Chows, Rhodesian Ridgebacks, Australian Cattle dogs, Jack Russell Terriers, Miniature Schnauzers, and Staffordshire Bull Terriers.

The CLCN1 gene codes for a protein called a chloride channel which aids in transportation of chlorine atoms through muscle membrane and generate & transmit electrical signals. A missense mutation on the gene disrupts this activity an results in Myotonia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of CLCN1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with canine Myotonia.
The treatment for this disease includes management with medications that stabilize the membrane and to reduce the symptoms
Physical aid is recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an inherited neuromuscular disorder caused due to absence of dystrophin protein leading to muscle atrophy and contractures. Affected dogs show stiffness in muscles, stiff gait, progressive weakening of muscles, difficulty swallowing, enlargement of tongue, diaphragm, and esophagus, difficulty swallowing, resistance to exercise, tremors, limb deformity and difficulty in breathing. The disorder is diagnosed by a muscle biopsy.
This disease has an early age of onset which can be between 1-3 months. The symptoms usually worsen with time and eventually lead to the demise of the dog.

The condition is reported in Australian Labradoodle, Border Collie, Brittany Spaniel, Cavalier King Charles Spaniel, German Shorthaired Pointer, Golden Retriever, Grand Basset Griffon Vendeen, Irish Terrier, Jack Russell Terrier, Japanese Spitz, Labrador Retriever, Miniature Schnauzer, Pembroke Welsh Corgi, Rat Terrier, Rottweiler, Samoyed, Tibetan Terrier and Weimaraner.

A nonsense mutation in DMD gene results in degraded dystrophin protein causing Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Inheritance is X-linked recessive with males affected more than females as male dogs carry only one X chromosome and females have two X chromosomes. Most of the females are unaffected carriers.
Timely medical management with proper physical aids required
Experimental Gene therapy with Crisper9 holds promise for future treatment options.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected female carrier parents in breeding programs

Mucopolysaccharidosis VII, (shepherd type) is a lysosomal storage disease characterized by accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAG), due to the lack of the lysosomal enzyme. Affected dogs typically present symptoms of bone and joint disease with disproportionally large heads with short muzzles, broad faces, low-set ears, broad chests, joint laxity, crooked legs, cloudy eyes, growth retardation and face difficulty to walk. Few dogs may also have cardiac issues. While affected dogs can survive with assistance for several years, poor quality of life is reported. Diagnosis is done by physical examination, blood enzyme studies and X-rays.

MPS VII disease has early onset and is progressive. As the disease progresses, standing becomes difficult and joints become swollen and are easily dislocated resulting in an inability to walk by 5 months of age. Additional clinical signs include cardiac abnormalities, tracheal narrowing, and glycosaminoglycans in the urine which makes the condition medically complex.
The condition is reported in German shepherd, Belgian Shepherd Dog, White Swiss Shepherd Dog and Brazilian Terriers.

Mucopolysaccharidosis VII (Shepherd Type) (MPS VII) is caused by a missense mutation in GUSB gene. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of GUSB gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with canine Mucopolysaccharidosis VII.
Although there is no complete cure, replenishing the hormones can delay prognosis and prolong life span.
If the disease is diagnosed at early stages, Intravenous Enzyme Replacement Therapy (ERT) can be useful
It is advised to restrict the dogs activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Mucopolysaccharidosis IIIa, is a rare lysosomal storage disease characterized by pathologic accumulation of heparan sulfate in tissues leading to progressive neurologic injury. Mucopolysaccharidosis III is also known as Sanfilippo syndrome. Symptoms include ataxia and loss of reflexes more severely affecting the hind limbs, head tremors, swaying, and abnormal eye movement. Diagnosis of this disease can be confirmed by observations of heparan sulfate in urine and accumulation in tissues, as well as decreased heparan N-sulfate catalytic activity in liver and cultured fibroblasts.

Typically dogs with MPS IIIB do not exhibit clinical signs until they reach two years of age. Clinical signs at this age include tremor and difficulty in balancing, walking, and negotiating obstacles such as stairs. The disease is progressive and there is no effective treatment. It leads to demise of the dog by 5 years of age.

The condition is reported in Dachshund, Miniature Longhaired Dachshund, Miniature Smooth Dachshund, Miniature Wirehaired Dachshund, Standard Longhaired Dachshund, Standard Smooth Dachshund and Standard Wirehaired Dachshund.

Mucopolysaccharidosis IIIa is caused due to a 3-bp deletion in SGSH gene. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of SGSH gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with canine Mucopolysaccharidosis IIIa.
Although there is no complete cure, replenishing the hormones can delay prognosis and prolong life span.
If the disease is diagnosed at early stages, Intravenous Enzyme Replacement Therapy (ERT) can be useful
It is advised to restrict the dogs activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Muscular hypertrophy, also called as Bully Whippet â€“ Whippet Double Muscling, is an inherited muscular disorder characterized by increased muscle mass. The trait is caused by a mutation in the myostatin (MSTN) gene. Myostatin regulates the size of muscles and prevents them from growing too large. Dogs that possess a single copy of this mutation in MSTN gene are more muscled than normal dogs, so they are chosen for competitive racing events. Double muscling in affected dogs are homozygous for the mutation (they have two copies of mutated genes) with muscle hypertrophy.

Musladin-Lueke Syndrome (MLS) , also called as Chinese beagle syndrome, is a inherited disorder affecting Beagle dogs  that manifests with extensive fibrosis of the skin and joints.Â It is multi-systemic, with involvement of multiple organs, including bone, heart, skin, and muscle. It is characterized by short stature, thick, taut skin, and severely restricted joint mobility in affected dogs with broad skulls, wide-set slanted eyes, creased ears and a hopping-tip-toe gait. Other characteristics of the disorder include a high-pitched bark and an exceptionally exuberant temperament.

Myasthenic syndrome, also called as congenital myasthenic syndrome (CMS), characterized by impaired neuromuscular transmission. Affected dogs have muscle weakness and hypertonicity of skeletal muscles, can run normally for few minutes, but then begin to take shorter and shorter strides. The signs disappear after several minutes of rest, but will recur if exercise is continued and eventually, they fall down with flexed legs. The diagnosis is based on electrophysiological test which determines the neuromuscular function using repetitive stimulation.
Myasthenic syndrome, congenital

Myotonia is an inherited disease, characterized by progressive muscle wasting and weakness. This causes muscle hypertrophy in dogs as well as noticeable stiffness upon rising to a standing position due to inability of chloride mobility and electrical instability in muscle membrane. Affected dog displays muscle stiffness, strange gait, enlarged tongue with difficulty to swallow, craniofacial structure anomalies and furrowing on several muscles when they are struck. The diagnosis of this disease depends upon the clinical signs, an electromyography (EMG) and a muscle biopsy report.
Myotonia

Myopathy of Great Danes (IMGD) is an inherited, rapidly progressing muscle myopathy characterized by exercise intolerance and progressive muscle atrophy. Clinical signs in affected dogs include exercise intolerance, muscle wasting, weakness, gait and postural abnormalities. Dogs may also have an abnormal posture with the hind legs tucked under the body and the tail extended. Occasionally they may exhibit difficulty in breathing. Diagnosis is done by physical examination and a muscle biopsy

Myotubular myopathy is an inherited disease, characterized by muscle weakness with symptoms ranging from mild to profound. Symptoms are present from birth which include generalized weakness, stilted gait, dysphagia, generalized muscle atrophy, inability to open the jaw, megaesophagus, and dysphonia (poor voice quality). The disease is diagnosed through Blood tests, electromyography (records the electrical activity of muscles), and a muscle biopsy.

Nacrolepsy is an inherited neurological disease, characterized by excessive sleepiness and brief attacks of cataplexy or muscle weakness is caused by low levels of a neuropeptide called orexin (hypocretin) in the brain which controls alertness and sleep patterns. Cataplectic attacks cause brief loss of voluntary muscle tone triggered by excitement, such as food or toys. Other symptoms include sudden collapse or falling, drooping spine, rapid eye movements or twitching, sudden unexplained sleep and lack of day time activity. The disease is diagnosed through X-rays and EEG.
Nacrolepsy

The neuronal ceroid lipofuscinoses (NCLs) are a group of heritable, lysosomal storage disorders characterized by progressive neurodegeneration accompanied by the accumulation of lysosomal storage granules in the central nervous system and other tissues. Signs appear in early stages, and include behavioral changes, nervousness, disorientation, ataxia, weakness, kyphosis, stiffness of gait, uncontrolled rhythmic head movements, and visual impairment. Fundic examination shows diffuse retinal thinning and retinal vessel degeneration. Diagnosis is usually done by physical examination, MRI and CT scan.

Neonatal Encephalopathy with Seizures is an inherited disease, characterized by progressive damage of brain. The symptoms usually appear early which include underweight, ataxia, whole-body tremors, wide-based stance with increased extensor tone weakness, mobility issues, seizures. The disease is usually diagnosed with MRI, X-rays and EEG. Cerebella of affected puppies may be reduced in size and often contained dysplastic foci consisting of clusters of intermixed granule and Purkinje neurons.

Nephritis is an inherited disease characterized by non inflammatory kidney malfunction. Due to the damage of kidney glomeruli, protein and red blood cells are lost through the urine resulting in edema or the accumulation of fluid within the body. The symptoms of this disease will include vomiting, poor appetite, weight loss, hearing loss, excessive thirst, excessive urination, lethargy, muscle weakness and anemia. Renal failure indicates end stage. The diagnosis of the disease can be done through Urine-analysis.

Neuroaxonal dystrophy is an inherited disease, characterized by progressive degeneration of neurons and abnormal nerve conduction. The Brain stem of the affected dog weighs lower than the unaffected dog. The symptoms include high stepping gait, poor coordination, tumbling, head tremors, incontinence, uncontrolled defecation, deficiency of vitamin E and secondary pneumonia. The disease can be diagnosed through complete blood count, serum chemistry profile, MRI and X-rays. The condition is usually lethal.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is an inherited skeletal disease characterized by fragile bones. The condition, which presents from birth is also known as Brittle bone disease and is caused due to poor collagen formation. The symptoms include spontaneous fracturing of the bones and teeth, loose joints, difficulty walking, pain, osteopenia, blue eye sclera, stunted growth, weak tendons and muscle atrophy. In severe extreme cases ribs can fracture leading to difficulty in breathing. The disease can be diagnosed through X-rays and radiography.
Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI)

Postoperative Hemorrhage in Greater Swiss Mountain dog is an inherited disorder of platelets characterized by excessive postoperative bleeding due to defect in platelet aggregation.  Affected dogs are usually asymptomatic but can show signs after a surgery or trauma. These dogs usually do not show any abnormalities on physical examination and may even go through life events, such as whelping, vaccinations, microchip implantation, with no reported problems. Evaluation of affected canine platelets by aggregometry would be useful to characterize the condition at the functional level. Neuronal damage can be seen in few affected dogs.

The symptoms include exercise intolerance, post exercise collapse and lactic acidosis leading to nausea, vomiting, severe breathing problems, and an abnormal heartbeat. The disease can be diagnosed through blood tests, urine analysis and MRI.

Pyruvate Kinase Deficiency is an inherited hemolytic anemia caused by a defect in the enzyme Pyruvate Kinase. Dogs with the enzyme deficiency have shortened red blood cell (erythrocyte) life span with slower regeneration erythtocytes and have sporadic episodes of hyperventilation induced intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria with signs of decreased exercise tolerance, tachycardia, systolic heart murmurs, and pale mucous membranes with anemia. Some dogs can develop bone marrow malignancy, osteosclerosis and cirrhosis of the liver. Blood work up required for diagnosis.

Primary Lens luxation is an inherited disorder caused due to the dislocation of the lens inside the eye due to weakness or degeneration of the lens zonules. It is characterized by the spontaneous displacement of the crystalline lens from its normal position. Lens Luxation causes inï¬‚ammation, glaucoma, increased intraocular pressure, resulting in painful, teary, red eyes that may look hazy or cloudy. The diagnosis is done by complete ophthalmic test. Immediate attention and medical care required to prevent complete blindness.

The age of onset is usually between 3-8 years of age with sudden signs of eye irritation, teary & red eyes that may look hazy or cloudy.  If not treated immediately after diagnosis, the disease can lead to Glaucoma and complete vision loss.
The condition is reported mostly in all Terrier breeds.

A mutation on in gene ADAMTS17, causes Primary Lens luxation. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of ADAMTS17gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Primary Lens luxation.
Although there is no cure, treatment like physical therapy and medications can be useful.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management. Ophthalmic test is recommended.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Canine polyneuropathy is an inherited neurological disorder characterized by a dysfunction of multiple peripheral nerves. Affected dogs suffer from slowly worsening exercise intolerance and may develop gait abnormalities, especially in the hind limbs that may progress to ambulatory paraparesis, in some severe cases deteriorating to non-ambulatory tetraparesis. Diagnosis of polyneuropathy is difficult, often requires a neurological examination and other tests such as ultrasound, X-ray, muscle biopsy and electronic testing of nerve response and activity.

The age of onset in affected dogs is usually between 3-9 months of age with exercise intolerance and an abnormal â€œbunny-hoppingâ€� gait.  As the disease progresses, affected dogs often show weakness in all four limbs, lose reflexes,  and show greater difficulties with walking and standing. In severe cases, demise occurs due to respiratory failure.
The condition is reported in Alaskan Malamute, Greyhound and Leonberger

This disorder is caused due to a 10 base pair deletion in NDRG1 gene which is essential for maintenance of the myelin sheaths in peripheral nerves. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of NDRG1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Canine Polyneuropathy.
Although there is no cure, treatment like physical therapy and medications can be useful.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Glaucoma is an inherited disease, characterized by blindness. This occurs due to increased Intra-Occular Pressure (IOP), primary form is due to genetic cause which is further divided into open angle type (painless with gradual development of loss of vision over a long period of time) and closed angle type (sudden increase in eye pressure with severe pain, redness, and followed by loss of vision. Symptoms include eye pain, appearance of vessels in the white of the eye, redness, cloudy cornea, watery eyes, light avoidance, weak blink response, no response of pupil to light, vision problems resulting in bumping into objects, difficulty finding toys, walking gingerly and bulging of the eye.  Diagnosis is based on Opthalmic examination, Tonometry, Electroretinography and X-rays.
Symptoms usually develop age of 6 years and in around 40% of the cases the dog becomes blind.
The condition is reported in Beagle, Norwegian Elkhound, Shiba-Inu and Shih-Tzu. Carrier frequency is recorded at 25.3% in Norwegian Elkhound.

A single base mutation in ADAMTS17 gene results in Primary Glaucoma. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of ADAMTS17 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Canine Glaucoma.
A balanced diet with Vitamin A rich food is recommended
Provide safe environment for pet to prevent injuries.

Treatment options may range from surgery, administration of beta-blockers, diuretics to reduce the fluid production, cholinesterase inhibitors, prostaglandin analogs and corticosteroids to control inflammation.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Polycythemia is an inherited disease characterized by a thickening of the blood, either due to a shortage of the amount of plasma in the blood or due to an increased number of red blood cells in circulation with ratio of plasma cells to red blood cells being unbalanced.  Affected dog shows abnormal behavior, difficulty breathing, enlarged liver, enlarged spleen, exhaustion, increased thirst, increased urination, lack of coordination, lethargy, nose bleeds, pale or brick red gums, seizures, sudden violent and recurring sneezing and Weakness. The disease can be diagnosed with blood tests, and urine analysis
This disease has an early age of onset at around 15 weeks and affected dogs usually have a shorter lifespan. If the condition is untreated, it can be lethal.
The condition is reported in Labrador retriever mixed breed, Yorkshire, Poodle, Maltese and Westie

The gene JAK2 (Janus Kinase 2) codes for a protein that sends signals and helps in controlling the number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets that are made in the bone marrow. A 6 base nucleotide change causes abnormal red blood cells formation. . It is an autosomal disorder with inheritance pattern unclear.
Oral administration of hydroxyurea and blood transfusions may be recommended by your veterinarian
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Canine polyneuropathy is an inherited neurological disorder characterized by a dysfunction of multiple peripheral nerves. Affected dogs suffer from slowly worsening exercise intolerance and may develop gait abnormalities, especially in the hind limbs that may progress to ambulatory paraparesis, in some severe cases deteriorating to non-ambulatory tetraparesis. Diagnosis of polyneuropathy is difficult, often requires a neurological examination and other tests such as ultrasound, X-ray, muscle biopsy and electronic testing of nerve response and activity.

The age of onset in affected dogs is usually between 3-9 months of age with exercise intolerance and an abnormal â€œbunny-hoppingâ€� gait.  As the disease progresses, affected dogs often show weakness in all four limbs, lose reflexes,  and show greater difficulties with walking and standing. Prognosis varies, while some dogs recover, in severe cases, demise occurs due to respiratory failure
The condition is reported in Alaskan Malamute, Greyhound and Leonberger

This disorder is caused due to a missense mutation in NDRG1 gene, which is essential for maintenance of the myelin sheaths in peripheral nerves. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of NDRG1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Canine Polyneuropathy.
Although there is no cure, treatment like physical therapy and medications can be useful.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Progressive retinal atrophy, Bassenji is an inherited disease only seen in Bassenji breeds. This disease is characterized by loss of vision with late age of onset. Progression of the disease leads to thinning of the retinal blood vessels by 6 or 7 years of age, signifying decreased blood flow to the retina. The symptoms of this disease include vision loss in dim light (night blindness) and loss of peripheral vision and thereby leading to complete vision loss.  The disease can be diagnosed through ophthalmic examination and retinography.

The first symptoms occur during dogâ€™s 5 to 7 years of age.  The first symptoms of progressive retinal atrophy, Bassenji type are poor vision in dim light, which eventually progresses into complete blindness.
The condition is reported in Bassenji breeds.

A mutation on the gene SAG gene causes degeneration of retinal photoreceptor cells leading to retinal atrophy. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of SAG gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Progressive retinal atrophy, Bassenji.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic for effective management.
Diet with Vitamin A rich food recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Prekallikrein deficiency is an inherited disease characterized by delay in blood clot. Prekallikrein (PK), or the Fletcher factor, is a serum protein which is homologous to factor XI and regulates clotting process. Affected dog may have hematuria (the presence of blood in the urine), gastrointestinal hemorrhage and excessive postoperative bleeding. The dog can also bruised easily and may have frequent nosebleeds. Sometimes, the symptoms are mild and may be not evident until a surgery is performed or trauma / injury occurs. The diagnosis of the disease is done by checking the clotting time.
Most of the time diagnosis is done after an injury or at the time of surgery when clotting time is analysed. The dog usually have a normal life span as the condition is not life threatening.
The condition is reported in Shih Tzu, Welsh Corgi and ShetlandSheepdog.

The gene KLKB2 (Kallikrein B, plasma (Fletcher factor 1) codes for Prekallikrein protein which  is a part of the blood clotting process. A missense variation in KLB2 gene causes deficiency of Prekallikrein thereby resulting in delay in blood clotting. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of KLKB2 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Prekallikrein deficiency.
Phenotypic diagnosis can be made on increased clotting time
Safe environment should be maintained in order to avoid injuries for affected dogs.
In case of surgeries on affected dog, ready access to suitable blood for transfusions must be planned.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Coat color, brown is an inherited trait controlled by TYRP1 (tyrosinase-related protein 1) gene that plays a role in the creation of the pigment eumelanin. A mutation in the TYRP1 gene can occur, causing a change in the production of the eumelanin. This dilutes the black color pigment into a brown color. This color can also be called as liver or chocolate. In some breeds (such as the Australian Shepherd), this color is referred to as red.

The trait is reported in Australian Shepherd, Border Colllie, Chesapeake Bay Retriever, Chinese Shar-Pei, Cocker Spaniel, Dachshund, Dalmatian, Doberman Pinscher, English Setter, English Springer Spaniel, English Pointer, Field Spaniel, Flatcoated Retriever, French Brittany Spaniel, German Shorthaired Pointer, German Longhaired Pointer, German Wirehaired Pointer, Griffon, Italian Greyhound, Labrador Retriever, Large Munsterlander, Newfoundland, Poodle, Portuguese Water Dog, Pudelpointer, Small Munsterlander and  Weimaraner.

Tyrp1 gene is involved inÂ stabilizing of tyrosinase protein and modulating its activity in skin pigment, melanin synthesis. A homozygous nonsense mutation results in brown coat. This condition follows autosomal recessive pattern with both copies of genes mutated to express the trait.

Rod Cone dysplasia 1a is an inherited eye disorder which affects the rod and cone photoreceptors resulting in visual acuity followed by severe loss of central and color vision that often progress to blindness. Retinal thinning and degeneration is characteristic. The clinical signs include early, severe, and rapidly progressive loss of cone function accompanied by progressive rod loss that is only relatively slower. Photoreceptors of inner and outer segmental layer are damaged, with rod inner segment more severely affected than those of cones. Diagnosis by ophthalmic evaluation and electroretinography.

Affected dogs typically have thinning and retinal degeneration by 11 weeks of age. Evidence of retinal thinning can be identified on a veterinary eye exam by 3 to 6 months of age. Vision is severely impaired by one year of age and by 20 months of age affected dogs have an advanced stage of retinal degeneration.
The condition is reported in Irish setters, American Staffordshire and Sloughi.

Rod Cone Dysplasia 1a is caused by a eight-base insersion in PDE6B gene which codes for the rod-specific essential component of the visual cascade protein. The gene is pivotal in phototransduction. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of PDE6B gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Rod Cone Dysplasia 1a
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured.
Diet with vitamin A rich food is recommended.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Epidermolysis Bullosa (EB) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by extreme fragility of the skin and mucosa, which causes unremitting blisters and erosions with unceasing wound healing. The disease may also affect other areas of the body (such as the mouth, throat, eyes, etc.) causing discomfort and, often, difficulties in carrying out vital activities. The diagnosis of this disorder is done by skin biopsy, immunohistochemistry and other blood tests along with physical examination.

Clinical signs of EB can be recognized soon after the dog's birth. Puppies have fragile skin that is easily damaged from rubbing or trauma resulting in blisters, ulcers and scarring of the skin. Areas that are most prone to blisters are the face, foot pads, genital areas and ears. Life span Is shortened in severe conditions.
The condition is reported in Golden Retriever, Central Asian Shepherd, Basset Hound, Goldendoodle and Groodl.

This disorder is caused by a missense mutation in COL7A1 gene impairing the formation of functional anchoring fibrils in the skin due to shortage of these fibrils. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of COL7A1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Epidermolysis Bullosa .
Â  The proper treatment of an affected dog includes regular combing, bathing in special shampoos, applying emollient ointments to help maintain a skin barrier and prevent excessive water loss.
A quality diet is essential; supplements of omega fatty acids are ideal.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs
