SCID is a rare immune genetic disorder characterized by the dogâ€™s inability to fight recurrent systemic or localized infections of the eye, ear or respiratory system. The T and B lymphocytes of the dog become dysfunctional resulting in a poor adaptive immune system. Clinical signs in affected dogs include diarrhea, development of epileptic seizures and vestibular ataxia, multifocal chronic encephalitis, multifocal pyrogranulomatous lesions in different organs and depletion of lymphoid tissues.  Severe combined immunodeficiency due to a mutation of RAG1 gene is reported to have high mortality rate.

The affected pups exhibit fallen puppy syndrome with diarrhea at ages 7â€“8 weeks and may respond to antibiotic treatment. However, subsequently they may develop neurological signs, such as epileptiform seizures, blindness and vestibular ataxia leading to early demise.
The condition was reported in Frisian Water Dog, Jack russell terrier, Basset hounds and Cardigan welsh corgi.

The RAG1 gene provides instructions for making a member of a group of proteins called the RAG complex crucial for functioning of immune system cells (lymphocytes) called B cells and T cells. A nonsense mutation in RAG1 gene disrupts the functionality of immune cells leading to poor recognition bacteria, viruses, and parasites. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of RAG1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with SCID.
Currently SCID is incurable and treatment options are limited to management with antibiotics and expensive bone marrow transplant procedure available only in selected centers in the world.
Experimental genetic therapy is currently being tested and holds potential
Keep the surrounding environment clean to avoid frequent infections
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Skeletal dysplasia 2 (SD2) is a mild form of disproportionate dwarfism in Labrador Retrievers. Affected dogs have short legs and their shoulder height is reduced by ~6 cm compared to non-affected dogs due to a minor dysfunction of collagen XI. The long bones may stop growing before being fully developed and often the front legs are more affected than the hind legs. The affected males usually have shoulder heights of less than 55 cm and affected females usually have shoulder heights of less than 50 cm. Apart from the shortened stature, dogs do not show any other clinical signs. Note that height is a complex trait controlled by both genetic and environmental factors.Â
The condition is mostly diagnosed at around 5-6 months of age and is NOT a progressive disorder.
Skeletal dysplasia 2 is reported in Labrador Retrievers. A carrier frequency of 12% was observed in the European Labrador Retriever population.

The gene COL11A2 (Collagen, type XI, alpha 2) provides instructions for making a component of type XI collagen that   provides structure and strength to the connective tissues that support the body's muscles, joints, organs. A missense mutation on COL11A2 gene results in cessation of long bone growth leading to Skeletal dysplasia 2. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of COL11A2 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with SCID. Please note that the mutation has been reported to have incomplete penetrance with variability in expression.
The condition is not painful and no treatment or management is required
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Brachycephaly is an inherited skeletal condition characterized by small skull with dog showing small and flattened face with small and wide skull. The dog might also exhibit loud breathing,  exercise intolerance, difficulty with heat tolerance, dyspnea, gagging when swallowing, everted laryngeal saccules, and a hypoplastic trachea. The affected dog may prone to frequent eye injuries, dental problems, skin infections and respiratory problems. The condition has multifactorial etiology.
This condition is congenital and in severe presentation the affected dog may have shorter life span.
Brachycephaly is seen in Shih Tzu, Boston Terrier, Boxer English Bulldog, French Bulldog, Pug and Pekingese.

The gene BMP3 (Bone Morphogenic Protein3) has role in bone induction, maintenance and repair. A missense mutation inhibits the function of the protein leading to brachycephaly.  The inheritance of the condition is not clear although some report autosomal semi-dominant pattern of inheritance.
Maintaining optimal weight by avoiding over feeding is important
Â Â Â  Keep the clean to avoid infections
In case of severe symptoms, surgery for widening the nostrils, removing the excess tissue of an elongated soft palate, or removing everted laryngeal saccules may delay the prognosis.

Ataxia, spinocerebellar, CAPN1-related, is an inherited disease characterized by progressive incoordination of gait and loss of balance.  The symptoms include problems with coordination and balance with â€˜dancing or prancingâ€™ gait display affecting the pelvic limbs, uncoordinated walk, involuntary eye movement and tremors.  At rest, dogs sometimes display a â€˜truncal swayâ€™ in a struggle to maintain balance. The diagnosis for the disease includes blood workup, urine analysis and MRI.
Symtoms are seen around 6â€“12 months of age. The condition is progressive and usually leads to early death of the dog.
The condition is reported in terrier breads such as Jack Russell Terrier, Smooth-Haired Fox Terrier and Parson Russell Terrier.

The gene CAPN1 (Calpain 1 (mu/l) large subunit 1) is crucial for neuron function. A missense mutation on CAPN1 gene disrupts enzymatic activity of cysteine proteases leading to neuronal necrosis and nerve cell dysfunction. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of CAPN1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Ataxia, spinocerebellar, CAPN1-related disorder.
Â Â  Early diagnosis and supportive care needed as there is no cure for the condition.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Â  Avoid stressful environment for the dog.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic. MRI and CT scan may be recommended

Ichthyosis, TGM1-related is an inherited condition, characterized by abnormal scaling of skin. The symptoms of a breed-specific Ichthyosis presents mild, moderate and severe phenotype with generalized scaling on the body, usually excluding the head, extremities, paw pads, and nose. The scales are initially a whitish color but become pigmented, progressing to gray or black, and they range in size from small to large. Early symptoms of the condition usually go unnoticed by owners. The disease can be diagnosed by physical examination and in some cases performing skin biopsy.
Symptoms are usually seen around 3-6 weeks of age but when mild they usually go unnoticed. This is a progressive condition with appearance of whitish color scales progressing to gray or black.
Ichthyosis TMG1â€“related is reported in Golden retrievers.

The gene TMG1 gene provides instructions for making Transglutaminase-1 enzyme mostly found in outermost layer of the skin. A frameshift mutation of the gene produces an altered protein product leading to Icthyosis. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of TMG1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Ichthyosis.
Using frequent mild anti-seborrheic shampoos and moisturizing rinses can delay the prognosis.
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an inherited blood disorder with impaired platelet aggregation and absent clot retraction. Clinical signs consist primarily of mucosal bleeding including nose bleeds, excessive gingival bleeding during tooth eruption, common bruises and petechia hemorrhages (tiny round, brown-purple spots due to bleeding under the skin). Blood tests including platelet count and immunology testing may be required for diagnosis. Affected dogs may also have frequent bloody noses, blood in the urine (hematuria), dark red-black tarry stool (melena), bruising of the skin and prolonged bleeding after surgery or trauma.
Onset of symptoms usually between 3-6 months. Affected dogs may show signs before one year of age with bleeding gums when their permanent teeth are erupting.
The condition is reported in Otterhounds.

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an inherited blood disorder with impaired platelet aggregation and absent clot retraction. Clinical signs consist primarily of mucosal bleeding including nose bleeds, excessive gingival bleeding during tooth eruption, common bruises and petechia hemorrhages (tiny round, brown-purple spots due to bleeding under the skin). Blood tests including platelet count and immunology testing may be required for diagnosis. Affected dogs may also have frequent bloody noses, blood in the urine (hematuria), dark red-black tarry stool (melena), bruising of the skin and prolonged bleeding after surgery or trauma.
Onset of symptoms usually between 3-6 months. Affected dogs may show signs before one year of age with bleeding gums when their permanent teeth are erupting.
The condition is reported in Great Pyrenees.

The ITGA2B gene provides instructions for a receptor complex which facilitates clotting by binding to fibrinogen. A 14 base pair insertion in the gene disrupts this activity and causes Thrombasthenia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of ITGA2B  gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Thrombasthenia.
The management of condition is often by platelet transfusion for the bleeding episodes.
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic. MRI and CT scan may be recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Thrombocytopaenia is an inherited disease, characterized by low platelet number, which decreases the dog's ability to control bleeding. Affected dogs are be easily bruised and may have excessive bleeding with injury. Other symptoms based on the severity of the episode may include severe or prolonged blood loss, fever, lethargy, heart murmur, and loss of appetite, weakness, urinary bleeding, nose bleeds, black tarry or bloody stools, excessive coughing and nasal mucus. In extremely severe cases dogs may suddenly collapse. The disease can be diagnosed by performing blood tests, including platelet count.
This disease has an early age of onset. The affected dog usually has a shorter life span.
The condition is reported in Cavalier King Charles Spaniels, Norfolk and Cairn Terriers

The gene TUBB1 (Tubulin, beta 1 class VI) codes for a protein which has a role in formation of microtubules expressed in platelets. A missence mutation can result in impaired microtubule assembly affecting proplatelet formation and platelet production in the blood. It is an autosomal dominant disorder, resulting when one copy of TUBB1 gene carry the mutation. Risk to offspring is 50%.
The management of condition is often by platelet transfusion during bleeding episodes
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic. MRI and CT scan may be recommended
Avoid using affected dogs  in breeding programs

Thrombopathia is an inherited bleeding disorder characterized by excessive bleeding.  The condition arises when the platelets do not respond to the injury. Symptoms include chronic mucosal bleeds, petechiae, aural hematomas and prolonged hemorrhage during estrus, shedding of deciduous teeth and after trauma or surgery. Depending on the severity of the injury other symptoms include abdominal lesions, blood in stool and urine, sastrointestinal tract bleeding, Iron deficiency, anemia and skin bruising. The disease can by diagnosed by performing Blood tests, platelet function test and APTT test.

Although the condition is congenital, symptoms may be seen only at the time of injury, surgery or while losing the tooth. If proper care is taken the affected dog can lead normal life and have normal life span. However 10-15% dogs with thrombopathia may develop severe symptoms leading to lethality.
The condition has been reported in Eskimo Spitz.

The gene RASGRP1 (RAS guanyl releasing protein 1 (calcium and DAG-regulated)) codes for a Rap 1 protein which is essential for platelets activation. A premature stop codon mutation leads to functional impairment of protein causing Thrombopathia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of RASGRP1 gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Thrombopathia
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic. MRI and CT scan may be recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Trapped Neutrophil syndrome is an inherited disease, characterized by decreased number of white blood cells (WBC) in the blood. Neutrophils, a type of WBC, produced by bone marrow are not transferred to the blood and hence called Trapped Neutrophil Syndrome. Affected dogs may have abnormally long head and legs, smaller in size compared to other puppies, exhibit inability to thrive, weakness, swollen joints, leg pain, lameness, frequent illnesses and susceptibility to infections. The dogs usually have higher than normal body temperature. The dogs may comparatively have shorter lifespan. Complete blood picture and bone marrow biopsy may be recommended for diagnosis
It is an early onset condition and symptoms appear at about 1 month. Rarely some dogs may show symptoms later in life. Life span is shortened, in some cases 5-6 months.
The condition is reported in Border coolie

The gene VPS13B (vascular protein sorting 13 homolog B (Yeast)) encodes a potential transmembrane protein responsible for transportation and sorting of proteins within the cell. A stop codon deletion on the gene stop results in non production of protein leading to trapped neutophils in bone marrow. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of VPS13B gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Trapped Neutrophil syndrome.
Management includes treatment with antibiotics, steroids and pain reducing medication
Keep the surrounding environment clean to avoid frequent infections
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Tremors X-linked is an inherited disease characterized by loss of coordination from brain to the body of the dog. It occurs when there is problem in the myelin sheath that covers nerve cells.  There is a delay in the communication of brain signal to body parts. Affected dogs may exhibit rhythmic tremors, repetitive and involuntary muscle movements looking like 'shaking' uncoordinated gait, sometimes not knowing relative position of their limbs leading to scuffing or dragging of the paws. Tremors may be localized to head part or may involve the entire body. These tremors may vary in severity, from very mild to incapacitating (preventing eating, walking, etc.). The disease can be diagnosed through an MRI.
The condition is usually an early onset type with symptoms arising at around 12 weeks. These symptoms usually worsen with time and eventually leading to early demise of the dog, within 3-4 months.

Shaking puppy Syndrome is reported in Miniature Dashund, Springer Spaniel, Australian Silky Terrier, Weimeraner, Golden Retriever, Catahoula Cur, Dalmatian, Chow Chow, Welsh Springer Spaniel, Vizsla, Samoyed, and Bernese Mountain Dog.

The gene PLP1 (proteolipid protein 1) plays a crucial role in the formation and maintenance of the multilamellar structure of myelin sheath. A missense mutation on the gene causes misfolding of protein leading to abnormal myelenation which causes tremors. The condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern and affects only male dogs. Female dogs are usually unaffected carriers.
Early diagnosis and supportive care needed as there is no cure for the condition
It is advised to restrict the dogâ€™s activities to as safe area where it cannot be injured
Avoid stressful environment for the dog.
Schedule regular visits to your Vet Clinic. MRI and CT scan may be recommended
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Vitamin D-deficiency rickets, type II is an inherited disease, characterized by hypocalcemia, secondary hyperparathyroidism, hypomineralization of bones and rickets. Poor intestinal absorption of calcium and insufficient calcium for growing skeleton is the reason behind the condition. Affected dogs have bone pain, stiff gait, swelling in the area of the metaphyses, difficulty in rising, bowed limbs, hypocalcemia, secondary hyperparathyroidism, joint pain, lameness, bone malformations and in some cases alopecia. Spontaneous fractures and pathologic fractures are reported. Diagnosis is done by physical examination, serum calcium and phosphate levels and X-rays
This disease has an early age of onset at around 4 months. Long exposure to sunlight is useful and has good prognosis. On the contrary dogs with irreversible bone damage may have shorter lifespan.
The condition is reported in Pomeranian breed.

The gene VDR gene provides instructions for making a protein called vitamin D receptor (VDR), which allows the body to respond to vitamin D. In the presence of a premature stop codon mutation, Vitamin D receptor is not produced leading to Vitamin D deficiency rickets, type II. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, resulting when two copies of VDR gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. Unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Vitamin D-deficiency rickets, type II.
Vitamin D rich food, balanced diet and exposure to sunlight is beneficial
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected carrier parents in breeding programs

Von Willebrand disease I is an inherited disease, characterized by excessive bleeding due to low concentration of vWF factor, which is essential for clotting of blood. The symptoms of this disease include Prolonged or excessive bleeding after an injury, bleeding from the gums or nose, Bloody urine, blood in the stool, easy bruising of the skin, excessive bleeding during surgical procedures such as spaying or neutering, prolonged bleeding of small wounds, bleeding after loss of baby teeth and anemia. The disease can be diagnosed through measurement of Von Willebrandâ€™s factor and clotting ability tests on blood and a complete blood count (CBC).
Symptoms are seen during a surgery or if the dog is injured. Severe prolonged bleeding episodes may lead to a shorter life span
The condition is reported in Doberman Pinscher, Shetland Sheepdog, KromfohrlÃ¤nder, German Shepherd Dog, and Standard Poodle.

The gene VWF provides instructions for making a blood clotting protein called von Willebrand factor crucial for formation of a blood clot. A frame shift mutation stops the production of VWF and results in Von Willebrand disease I. It mostly is an autosomal dominant disorder, resulting when one copy of VWF gene carry the mutation. Risk to offspring is 50%.  However, some studies also report autosomal recessive inheritance where two copies of VWF gene carry the mutation, one copy inherited from each parent. In such an inheritance, unaffected carrier parents have 25% risk of having a pup with Von Willebrand disease I. Incomplete penetrance is also recorded

Although there is no permanent cure, treatment aims at reducing and managing bleeding episodes in dogs by transfusions. Make sure cryoprecipitate, which is particularly rich in von Willebrand's factor, is readily available in case of planned surgeries. Vasopressin drugs such as DDAVP are also helpful.
Soft diet is recommended
Avoid using affected dogs  in breeding programs.

The white spotting is an inherited trait, characterized by the presence of white spotting phenotype. The Dog acquired with this trait appears to have pattern that includes white markings on the face, ventral abdomen, feet and tip of the tail, similar to the patterns observed in other species.  The variable expressivity of the white spotting pattern is considerable, and it could result either from stochastic developmental processes or from other heritable variants.
The trait is reported in German shepherd.

In german shepherd, KIT gene governs the coat color phenotypic outcomes and the mutation on the gene KIT gene signaling, causing deficit of melanoblasts (a type of skin cells that impart color). This results in areas of the skin being devoid of melanocytes and thus non-pigmented. This condition is follows autosomal dominant pattern with only one allele / copy enough to express the trait. Please note that double copy of the mutation can be lethal.
Coat colour, white spotting, KIT-related

SCID is a rare immune genetic disorder characterized by the dogâ€™s inability to fight recurrent systemic or localized infections of the eye, ear or respiratory system. The T and B lymphocytes of the dog become dysfunctional resulting in a poor adaptive immune system. Clinical signs in affected dogs include diarrhea, development of epileptic seizures and vestibular ataxia, multifocal chronic encephalitis, multifocal pyrogranulomatous lesions in different organs and depletion of lymphoid tissues.
Early onset of symptoms seen by the age of 2-3 weeks. The symptoms usually worsen with time and eventually lead to early demise of the dog by 4 months.
The condition is reported in Basset Hound and Cardigan Welsh Corgi

The IL2RG gene provides instructions for making a protein called the common gamma chain which is a crucial component of body immune system. A premature termination mutation disrupts the functionality of the gene and results in SCID. The condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern and affects only male dogs. Female dogs are usually unaffected carriers
Currently SCID is incurable and treatment options are limited to management with antibiotics and expensive bone marrow transplant procedure available only in selected centers in the world.
Experimental genetic therapy is currently being tested and holds potential
Keep the surrounding environment clean to avoid frequent infections
Avoid using affected dogs and unaffected female carrier parent in breeding programs
